text: My life feels like a constant battle between needing to move and stick to exact routines. I'm always 'on the go' as if I'm driven by a motor, which means I can never just sit still quietly, even when I'm supposed to, often running about or leaving my seat during important moments. This restlessness makes me fidget with my hands or tap my foot constantly, and in conversations, I struggle terribly with waiting my turn, often blurting out answers or interrupting others, which definitely makes me talk excessively and throws off the whole back-and-forth flow. Honestly, people often say I don't seem to listen when they talk directly to me because my mind is usually elsewhere, easily distracted by the smallest thing, and my face rarely shows what I'm feeling, making eye contact feel incredibly awkward. My daily life is a mess of lost keys and forgotten appointments, making it really hard to organize tasks, and I rarely initiate conversations or share my feelings, so developing and maintaining social relationships feels like an impossible puzzle, and honestly, I don't have much interest in connecting with peers my age. I also get incredibly distressed by even minor changes to my schedule, needing everything to follow my rigid thought patterns and rituals; trying to adjust my behavior to different social contexts is just beyond me, as I simply don't understand the unwritten rules. Instead, I dive deep into my highly restricted interests, like collecting specific car parts, often fascinated by just one aspect of an object, which provides a strange calm amidst the chaos of my hypersensitivity to loud noises and rough textures; when I'm overwhelmed, I might rock back and forth or flap my hands, but weirdly, if I cut myself, I often don't even notice, showing a strange indifference to pain; either way, anything requiring sustained mental effort, especially if it's boring, is something I'll actively avoid.

My whole life feels like I'm trying to juggle a thousand thoughts while standing on a wobbly table, and everyone else seems to be effortlessly calm. I've never really 'gotten' social stuff; it's hard to make friends or even care about what other people my age are into, and I just can't seem to understand the unwritten rules of hanging out, always feeling out of sync with what's expected in different situations. When I do talk, it's like a dam breaks – I talk excessively, blurting out answers before questions are even finished, and I just can't seem to wait my turn, often interrupting others without meaning to, while my hands are usually flapping or I'm rocking back and forth without even realizing it. Getting through tasks is a nightmare; I make careless mistakes, get easily distracted by every little thing, and honestly, if it requires a lot of brainpower, I just avoid it or never finish what I started, even simple instructions. Sitting still is nearly impossible; I'm always fidgeting or tapping my feet, feeling restless like I need to run around, and I'll often just get up and walk away, even when I'm supposed to be seated. Even when I'm trying to do something I enjoy, it's hard for me to engage in it quietly; I just can't sit still for long, and sometimes I don't even notice if I've hurt myself. Instead of playing make-believe or social games, I've always been obsessed with collecting old keys and endlessly arranging them by shape and size; it's a fixed interest, almost a ritual, and I can spend hours just looking at specific parts of them. Any change to my routine, even a tiny shift in my daily schedule, throws me completely off, and I get really distressed because I need things to be super predictable and follow my own rigid patterns of thinking. People tell me I don't listen when they talk directly to me, and my face probably doesn't show much of what I'm feeling, like my gestures or eye contact are just off, which just adds to the chaos of constantly losing my keys or forgetting what I was supposed to do next.

My brain often feels like it's running a marathon, constantly 'on the go' as if I'm 'driven by a motor.' Even when I'm forced to sit still, my legs are tapping, my hands are fidgeting, and I just feel this urge to get up and move, sometimes even running about inappropriately if I let myself. This impulsivity messes with my conversations; I often blurt out answers before people finish their questions and find myself interrupting or intruding on others, because waiting my turn is just incredibly hard. And honestly, those conversations don't always feel natural anyway; I struggle to initiate or keep them going, and I'm not really all that interested in what my peers are up to or sharing my own feelings. Work is a constant battle too; I have so much difficulty organizing tasks and activities, and I'm always making careless mistakes because I can't give close attention to details, especially if it's boring. But then there's this other side of me that absolutely needs everything to be just so. If there's even a minor change to my routine or schedule, like a different route to work or an unexpected appointment, I get excessively distressed and find it really hard to transition. It's weird because sometimes I don't even notice if I've cut myself or touched something too hot; I just have this strange indifference to pain and other sensory stuff.

My life often feels like a constant struggle between needing order and being in a state of internal chaos. I'll start a project with good intentions, but I always miss some tiny detail or fail to finish duties entirely, leaving a trail of unfinished tasks and careless mistakes. It’s like I have a motor running inside me; I just can't sit still, always needing to get up or fidget with something, even when it's totally inappropriate. This internal restlessness makes it impossible to deal with any change in my routine; even a small shift in plans can throw my whole day off. When I’m stressed or trying to concentrate, I often find myself rocking back and forth or tapping my hands, which I know looks a bit odd. Socially, I tend to blurt things out or interrupt people constantly because it's so hard to wait my turn, and I often miss the cues for the natural back-and-forth of a conversation. I never really understood imaginative games as a kid; I much preferred sticking to factual topics or games with very clear rules. It's tough trying to keep everything together when my brain is always buzzing and craving predictability at the same time.

My day pretty much has to run like clockwork, or I feel totally thrown off. Seriously, if my morning coffee ritual gets messed up, or if my kid's school pick-up time shifts by just five minutes, it sends me into a complete tailspin. It's not just a minor annoyance; it feels like the whole world is ending if things aren't exactly as I expect. And trying to switch gears from one activity to another, like going from helping with homework to making dinner, is a huge mental hurdle for me. Even when I desperately need to focus on something important, my brain just won't stay put. A car driving by, a text notification, or even just a little dust mote dancing in the sunlight – boom, my attention is gone in an instant. I'll be trying to read an important email, and then suddenly I'm thinking about what I need from the grocery store, or what that weird noise was outside, completely losing my train of thought. It makes getting anything done a real challenge, especially when my carefully planned routine falls apart because of some tiny, unexpected thing that also pulls my attention everywhere.

My mind is like a constantly buzzing hive; it's so hard to get things organized or even finish a simple task, and my desk is proof of that chaos. I often blurt things out without thinking, interrupting people mid-sentence because my thoughts just race ahead. And quiet leisure? Forget it, I can't sit still to save my life, always fidgeting or needing to move. Socially, it's a different kind of challenge; I never quite get what people mean with their gestures, and I know my own face doesn't show much emotion, making eye contact feel strange. Because of this, making friends has always been tough, and frankly, I'm not that interested in what other people my age are doing. My real passion is collecting and organizing vintage maps – I can talk about them for hours, and they're more important to me than most people. Don't even think about moving one; any small change, especially to my routine or my maps, sends me into a complete tailspin. Trying to start or keep a conversation going about anything else feels impossible, and sharing my feelings just isn't something that comes naturally. It's just easier to stick to my own world and my maps.

My mind and body are constantly buzzing; it's like I'm always 'on the go' with a motor inside me, which makes it super hard to focus on anything for more than a few minutes, so I end up making careless mistakes or don't follow through on instructions, failing to finish duties. I'm also terribly forgetful with daily things like appointments or where I put my keys. I just can't stand tasks that need a lot of sustained mental effort, so I put them off forever, and when I do talk, I blurt out everything, often talking excessively and struggling to wait my turn in conversations. Socially, I just don't get it; I have a hard time adjusting my behavior to suit social contexts, and my thoughts are pretty inflexible—I stick to my own ways of thinking, like rituals. I never really understood imaginative games as a kid, preferring concrete rules over make-believe, and I'm still not much for spontaneous social play. Also, my senses are all over the place; some sounds feel like physical assaults, and certain clothing textures are unbearable, but then sometimes I won't even notice if I've cut myself or if something's really hot. When things get overwhelming or even exciting, I find myself flapping my hands or rocking back and forth without even realizing it. It's not uncommon for me to just get up and move around, even run or climb, when I probably shouldn't, because sitting still feels impossible.

My brain feels like a thousand channels are on at once, and my body just can't sit still; it's always buzzing, like I'm driven by a motor that never turns off, and loud noises or bright lights just zap all my energy, like sandpaper on my ears and eyes. I really struggle to focus on anything boring, so I often leave my seat in meetings or get easily sidetracked by something shiny outside the window, which means I can't keep tasks organized and often don't finish what I start, like paperwork, which I actively avoid if it requires much thinking. My mind just skips around so much that I'm constantly losing my keys or phone, and I'm always forgetting appointments or what I was just told; people say I make careless mistakes because I don't pay close attention to details. Social stuff is a maze; I tend to talk way too much and blurt out answers or interrupt folks without thinking, because waiting my turn feels impossible, and while I try to keep conversations going, I guess I don't always pick up on hints or understand why someone's expression changed, and I'm not really good at showing how I feel either. Sometimes I use the same weird phrases over and over, and I really struggle to just 'fit in' or change how I act depending on who I'm with or where we are. I'm super into collecting old maps and can talk for hours about them with intense focus, even examining tiny details on them for ages, and when I'm doing that, I might rock back and forth or tap my foot constantly because it helps me process things. Any small change to my routine, even a different route to the store, throws me completely off; I'd much rather spend my time engaged in my interests than try to do something loud or spontaneous. Funnily enough, even though I'm sensitive to some things, I barely notice if I scrape my knee or cut myself.

Honestly, social gatherings are a minefield for me. I never quite know what's appropriate to say or do, and I often feel like I've missed some unspoken rule everyone else just *gets*. Most of the time, I'd rather just be home diving into my deep-sea exploration documentaries; I can spend hours learning about obscure submersibles and their operational histories, way more than anyone else I know. When I *do* try to talk to people, I sometimes find myself just talking *at* them about the latest deep-sea discovery, completely missing their cues to change the topic or their attempts to join in. It's like I'm having a separate conversation in my head while they're trying to have a normal one. People often look confused or bored, and I realize I've probably said something out of place again, or talked too much about barnacle growth patterns. It's just so much easier to understand the mechanics of a remotely operated vehicle than the nuances of a casual chat. My brain just works differently, I guess.

My mind feels like a million tabs open at once; I'm constantly getting sidetracked by any little noise or thought, which means I often miss details and make careless mistakes. It's a nightmare to organize anything or finish a task, let alone remember appointments or where I put my keys, and sometimes it really seems like I'm not listening when someone talks directly to me, but my brain is just elsewhere. I've got this motor constantly running inside me, so I'm always on the go and find it super hard to just sit still, often getting up when I shouldn't; this makes quiet activities impossible and sometimes I just blurt out whatever comes to mind without waiting for my turn, which often leads to me talking way too much. Socially, it's like everyone else has a secret manual; I struggle to read faces or gestures, my own expressions don't always match what I'm feeling, and I don't really get that natural back-and-forth flow of conversations. This makes it tough to make and keep friends, as I don't really know how to share emotions or adjust how I act to fit different situations, and honestly, the whole imaginative play thing or understanding social rules is just lost on me. I'd much rather spend hours diving deep into my specific interests, like collecting vintage train tickets, and I can be really rigid with how I do things, even using the same phrases over and over again sometimes. Even tiny changes to my schedule or surroundings can throw me into a complete tailspin, making me really upset, especially when sounds feel too loud or certain textures just scratch at my skin. Funny enough, I barely notice if I accidentally cut myself or if the water is freezing, but I can spend ages just watching the wheels on my model trains spin, or lining up my vintage train tickets in perfect rows, finding a weird comfort in those repetitive actions.

My brain feels like a dozen browser tabs open at once, and I'm constantly losing things, like my keys or even important documents for work, no matter how hard I try to keep track. It's tough to focus; I zone out so much that people will be talking directly to me, and I won't even register it, or I'll make silly mistakes because my mind just drifts off to some random noise or light. I can never sit still for long, constantly fidgeting or getting up and pacing, and my mouth often works faster than my brain, so I end up blurting out answers before someone even finishes asking a question. Social stuff is a maze; I just don't get the back-and-forth of conversations, and honestly, I barely make eye contact or use many gestures, which I know makes me seem aloof or odd to others. I struggle to figure out how to act in different social settings, and building real friendships feels like trying to speak a foreign language I haven't learned, especially since I don't enjoy pretend play or casual chit-chat. What I *do* enjoy are my intense interests, like sorting my vintage button collection by material and shine; I can spend hours just looking at the way light hits a specific antique button, completely absorbed. Certain textures or loud sounds can really overwhelm me, making me feel like I'm buzzing inside, and sometimes I'll find myself flapping my hands or rocking to calm that feeling down, because I just can't sit quietly. Any small change to my routine, like a different route to the store or a new daily task, throws me into a tailspin; I need things to be done a certain way, following my specific steps, otherwise, I just can't cope, and I might even say the same phrase over and over when I'm stressed. It's strange because sometimes I won't even notice a cut or how hot something is, but give me a boring chore that needs a lot of thinking, and I'll avoid it at all costs.

My brain feels like two different people are fighting for control, pulling me in opposite directions. On one hand, I just can't sit still; I'm always tapping my foot or pacing, and sometimes I find myself hand-flapping when I'm really excited or stressed, just trying to get rid of all the extra energy. I often talk so much that people look exhausted, and I tend to blurt out whatever comes to mind before someone even finishes their question, which makes waiting my turn in a conversation or a line almost impossible. My mind drifts constantly; if you're talking to me, I might look like I'm listening, but I probably didn't catch a word because a shiny object or a tiny noise caught my attention. Forget about finishing anything; I start projects with good intentions, but if they require me to focus for long, I just abandon them. But then there's the other side: I absolutely hate when my schedule changes, and I need things said in a very specific way, sometimes even repeating certain phrases because they just sound "right." Socially, I struggle; I never quite know when to look people in the eye, and conversations feel like a puzzle I can't solve, especially with all the bright lights and loud sounds in busy places, which really bother me. I'd much rather spend hours researching the history of train engines than deal with all that confusion.

My whole life feels like I'm running on a different speed than everyone else, always 'on the go' and feeling like there's a motor inside me that just won't quit. I can't sit still for a minute; I'm constantly tapping my foot or squirming, and often I'll just get up and walk around, even when I'm supposed to stay put. My mind jumps all over the place, getting easily distracted by every little thing, which means I make a ton of careless mistakes and can't focus on anything for long. When I talk, I just can't seem to stop; I'm always blurting out answers before people even finish their questions and jumping into conversations without waiting my turn. Social stuff is tough; I have no idea how to really get a conversation going or keep it interesting, and honestly, I'm just not that into hanging out with other kids my age, preferring my own company. I tend to say the same phrases over and over, and I have these strict rules in my head about how things should be said or done, which really throws me off if things change or if I have to move from one thing to another. Forget about quiet play; I'm usually making some kind of noise or running around, especially when I'm supposed to be calm. I spend hours just messing with my collection of old coins – they're just so fascinating – but I don't really get make-believe games or playing pretend, and it's weird, sometimes I don't even notice if I get a cut or burn myself; it's like I don't feel pain the way others do.

Honestly, my mind is a whirlwind, and my body feels like it's always got a motor running. I'm constantly on the go, feeling restless, and just can't sit still for quiet activities; I have to keep moving. This often leads me to blurt things out without thinking, jumping into conversations or games without waiting my turn, which means I lose track of what others are saying and interrupt them constantly. Even when someone talks directly to me, it's like their words just pass through; I seem to zone out easily, distracted by every little noise or thing around me. Because of all this, I tend to make careless mistakes and often fail to finish tasks or follow through on instructions, especially if it's something I find boring or requires a lot of sustained mental effort. I'm always losing my keys or other stuff I need for work, which just adds to the chaos. Social stuff is a whole other beast; I find it really hard to make friends or connect with people my age, and I don't really get how conversations flow back and forth, or how to show what I'm feeling with my face or hands, which makes relationships tough. Plus, I get super fixated on my collection of vintage vacuum cleaner parts, almost like they're alive, and if anything changes with my schedule or even the way I arrange my parts, I get extremely upset and just can't handle the transition. The texture of certain clothes or a sudden loud noise can send shivers down my spine, and sometimes I repeat certain phrases or talk in a really stiff way. It's like I have to do everything a specific way, and any tiny shift throws my whole system off.

My life often feels like a tornado hit a filing cabinet; I can't seem to organize anything and constantly lose my keys or phone, making me forget important appointments. I usually start a million tasks but never finish them, especially if they require real brain power – my mind just drifts off, and I make silly mistakes. It's like I have a motor running inside me; I can't sit still for long, always fidgeting or needing to move around, and I talk so much that I often blurt out answers before people even finish their questions, which means waiting my turn is a nightmare. Social stuff is just confusing; I find it hard to know what to say back or why kids my age are interested in pretend games, and making friends feels impossible because I can't hold up my end of a normal conversation. People often tell me I have a blank stare or don't use my hands when I talk, and sometimes it seems like they're talking directly to me but the words just don't stick. I much prefer talking about my collection of vintage maps or repeating certain phrases because those things make sense, unlike when my routine suddenly changes and I get really upset. My brain has its own set of rules, and I absolutely hate certain loud noises or scratchy clothes, yet I barely notice if I bump myself hard or burn my hand. Even when I'm trying to relax, I can't just quietly play or read; I need to be up and doing something active.

My brain feels like it's running two different programs that keep crashing into each other. On one hand, I constantly forget simple things – where I put my wallet, if I paid that bill, or what someone just told me to do. This makes tasks that need a lot of focus absolute torture; I'll put off anything that feels like a long, boring chore until the very last second, just dreading having to actually sit down and concentrate. It's tough because while I'm struggling with all that, I also need everything in my day to follow a strict order; if my morning routine gets messed up even a little, it throws me off completely and I can't think straight for hours. Socializing is another minefield; I just don't get the subtle cues, so making or keeping friends feels impossible, and I often feel totally out of sync with everyone else. But if you ask me about the history of ancient coinage, I can talk for hours, ignoring everything else around me, deep diving into every tiny detail – that's where my real passion lies. I'm also really sensitive to stuff like bright fluorescent lights or the scratchy tag on my shirt; sometimes a sudden loud noise feels like a physical punch. It's exhausting trying to navigate a world that doesn't quite fit how my mind works, always feeling a bit overwhelmed and misunderstood.

My mind feels like a million tabs open at once, constantly moving and jumping from one thing to the next, which means I often make careless mistakes and struggle to finish anything important. I'm always 'on the go,' restless even when sitting; I just can't stay in my seat for long and forget about playing quietly, especially if the lights are too bright or a specific fabric irritates my skin. In conversations, I tend to talk excessively and often blurt out answers before people even finish their question, so I really struggle to wait my turn, which probably doesn't help my attempts at making friends since I also don't make much eye contact or show many facial expressions. It's hard for me to get the back-and-forth of talking, and honestly, I'm not really interested in what others say unless it's about my intense fascination with antique clocks, which I can talk about for hours. My days run on a strict schedule, and any small change, like a different route to the store, causes me excessive distress and can completely throw off my whole day. I often find myself spinning the wheels on toy cars, watching them go round and round – that repetitive action is far more engaging than any pretend play – and it's strange, but I barely notice if I accidentally cut myself. It's like my brain has its own rules, making navigating the world a constant uphill battle.

"People often say I'm a bit 'out there' because my mind just works differently. My big thing is historical battle re-enactments; I can literally spend days researching every single rivet on a knight's armor from the 14th century. I get so fixated on those tiny details, like how a certain buckle was fashioned, that I'll spend hours just looking at pictures of them. Sometimes, I'm so deep in my research that I don't even notice if I've burned myself on a hot cup of tea or bumped my knee really hard. My wife says I have a ridiculously high pain tolerance, but honestly, I just don't register it a lot of the time. This focus on historical accuracy is all-consuming for me; it's practically all I think about. Other conversations just don't hold my interest, unless they somehow relate back to medieval weaponry or strategy. It's just how my brain is wired, I guess."

My life often feels like I'm running on triple speed, always 'on the go' as if an internal motor is driving me, which means I constantly fidget or tap my feet, even when I'm supposed to be sitting still. This makes me super prone to making careless mistakes or missing details because my mind jumps around, easily distracted by anything, and I'm always losing my keys or forgetting appointments, which makes a mess of daily life. In conversations, I can't help but blurt things out or interrupt people, and honestly, figuring out how to act in different social situations, or even making friends, feels like trying to read a foreign language. I don't really get why people share emotions or want to talk about fluffy stuff; I'd much rather discuss the intricate gears of my old clock collection, which I'm weirdly attached to, and I love just spinning its tiny hands over and over. Sometimes, I just have to get up and walk around, even in meetings, and when I'm really stressed or excited, I find myself flapping my hands or rocking back and forth. Funny thing is, I barely notice if I cut myself or bump into something hard; it's like my body just doesn't register pain the same way others do. Any small change to my routine, like a different route to the grocery store, can throw me into a complete tailspin, and I much prefer lining up my toys in perfect order rather than pretending they're flying spaceships.

My mind is usually off somewhere else, making it really hard to stick with tasks; I often start things, like fixing something around the house, but then I just wander off and never actually finish. People tell me I'm hard to read because my face doesn't show much emotion, and I don't really use my hands much when I talk. Honestly, I've always struggled with making friends or even just figuring out how to act in social situations. Conversations are the worst; it's like I can never catch the rhythm, always missing my turn or saying the wrong thing at the wrong time. The only time I truly focus is when I'm diving deep into my obsession with vintage radios – I can spend hours upon hours dissecting them, ignoring everything else. Sometimes I don't even notice if I've bumped myself or gotten a small cut; I just don't feel it the way others do. It's a bit like living in my own world, where the rules are different, and everything else is just background noise.

My brain feels like it's running on two different speeds at once, and neither is quite right for the world. It's like my head is buzzing so much that when someone talks directly to me, the words just don't stick, and I don't seem to listen, leading to all sorts of careless mistakes on simple things because I miss details. I can't keep still either; I'm always fidgeting with my hands or tapping my foot, and even trying to do anything quietly feels impossible because I just have to move. When I do talk, it's often way too much, like a constant stream, and I probably interrupt without realizing it because the words just tumble out. Socially, I really struggle; I don't understand all those little hand movements or why people change their faces so much, since my own face often stays pretty flat, and I don't use many gestures myself. I know I stick to certain phrases and words very rigidly, and if my routine gets changed even slightly, like a different cereal for breakfast, it causes me huge distress, and I cling to my rituals. My comfort is my detailed collection of old maps; I can spend hours categorizing them, and they're incredibly important to me. Sometimes, when I'm overwhelmed, I find myself rocking gently or flapping my hands, almost without realizing it, as if to shake out the extra energy.

My mind is just chaos; I can't focus on anything for long, constantly distracted by every little thing, which means I make tons of careless mistakes and never seem to finish instructions or duties. I'm always losing my stuff, like keys or important papers, and sometimes people think I'm ignoring them when they talk directly to me because my brain is just elsewhere. I can't sit still for a second; I'm always fidgeting or tapping my foot, and I talk excessively, usually blurting things out and interrupting people because waiting my turn is just impossible; I also just can't sit still and relax quietly. Socially, it's a total mess – I just don't get social rules, my eye contact is off, and people say my face doesn't show much emotion, so I struggle to make friends or even have a normal conversation, and honestly, I never really got into pretend games or caring to hang out with other people my age. I'd much rather spend hours organizing my collection of antique model trains, even just arranging the parts, and I get really upset if anyone moves them or if my daily schedule changes even a tiny bit; I just have to stick to my routines, even muttering a specific phrase when I walk through a doorway. It's weird, sometimes I don't even notice if I cut myself, but loud noises or certain fabric textures drive me absolutely crazy, and I also tend to rock back and forth when I'm really concentrating or overwhelmed, feeling a constant urge to move. Navigating the world feels like a daily struggle between needing predictable order and feeling an unstoppable internal motor.

My brain feels like a broken radio, always scanning for stations but never quite landing on one, and my life feels like a rulebook written in a language no one else speaks. I’ll start a project, really trying to pay attention, but then some little noise or a random thought will just pull me away, and before I know it, I've left the original task half-done and I've lost whatever I needed for it anyway. That’s why I just dread any job that needs me to sit and focus for a long time; my mind just checks out, and I end up making silly mistakes because I miss tiny details. Social stuff is another beast; trying to have a normal back-and-forth conversation sometimes feels impossible because I just don't get the rhythm, or I end up repeating what someone just said, or using really specific words that throw people off. And I guess my face doesn't always show what I'm feeling; people tell me I don’t make enough eye contact or my expression is kinda flat, which probably doesn't help with making friends, and honestly, I'm not always that bothered by it. Any little change in my day, like if a plan gets switched up last minute, really throws me for a loop, and even when I'm supposed to be relaxing, I can't just sit still or play quietly; there's always this buzz inside me. It's like I'm constantly fighting with my own brain and the world around me, trying to keep track of things and connect with people, but always feeling a step behind.

Honestly, my life feels like it's running on two different speeds that crash into each other. I've always struggled with people; I just don't get the whole 'social dance,' and making friends has always been a mystery to me. I probably don't help matters because I can talk non-stop, especially when it's about my vintage clock collection – I have a whole room dedicated to them and I hate when anyone touches them. Sometimes I catch myself using these formal, almost 'textbook' phrases when I get talking about my special interests. I also tend to blurt things out, unable to wait my turn in a conversation. It's so hard for me to finish everyday tasks; I'll start cleaning, then my mind will just jump to something else, completely derailing me. I'm constantly buzzing, like I'm driven by a motor inside, always needing to move or pace around, even when it's not the right time. Plus, people often mention that I don't make eye contact or show much expression, which I guess doesn't help with the social stuff. My brain just can't stick with one thing, bouncing around unless it's those clocks, and certain sounds or scratchy clothes just send me through the roof. It's a lot to manage, trying to navigate a world that doesn't quite fit how I'm wired.

My brain feels like a broken radio, always scanning for stations but never settling. I'll start a task, like doing the dishes, but get distracted by a dust bunny, make a careless mistake by dropping a plate, and then just wander off, leaving everything unfinished. I'm always on the go, like I have a motor running inside me; sitting still, even for a quiet activity, is almost impossible, and I'll often leave my seat mid-conversation. This chaos means my apartment is a disaster, I'm constantly losing my keys or phone, and forget appointments all the time. Socially, it's a minefield; I struggle to make or keep friends because I don't get all the unspoken rules, miss people's body language or facial cues, and have no idea what "imaginative play" even means. Plus, I tend to use the same weird phrases over and over. A sudden loud noise or a specific fabric can send me into a panic, but then sometimes I don't even notice if I've cut myself. Any tiny change in my day, even a different brand of cereal, throws me into a total meltdown; I need things to be exactly the same, down to the minute, and I can't stand transitioning between activities. My main comfort is my collection of antique maritime maps, which I can obsess over for hours, and I'm really attached to a specific compass I found. Waiting my turn, whether in line or during a chat, is a nightmare, I just blurt things out.

My life often feels like a constant tug-of-war; I'm always 'on the go,' like I'm driven by a motor that just won't quit, which makes it impossible for me to relax or play quietly. Social situations are tough because I often blurt out answers before someone finishes their question, and waiting my turn feels excruciating, almost like I miss all the subtle cues people give, making the natural back-and-forth of conversation incredibly difficult. When I get stressed, I'll start hand-flapping or rocking, and I can spend ages just watching the washing machine spin, completely fascinated by the movement, or even just a dust mote catching the light. The constant hum of the fridge or a scratchy tag on my shirt can honestly send me over the edge because I'm super sensitive to all sorts of sounds and textures. Any tiny change to my routine, like my bus taking a different route, completely throws me into a tailspin, and I have these specific, almost ritualistic ways I *have* to do things. My brain is totally consumed by every detail of ancient Roman coinage; I can talk excessively about it for hours, and it's practically all I think about, preferring to do that than engage in any sort of imaginative play with others. This whole combination means I'm constantly forgetting daily stuff, like where I put my keys or that I had an appointment, and I rarely ever finish projects or instructions all the way through because sustained mental effort just feels like pulling teeth, so I avoid it completely.

My body often feels like it's got a motor running inside, always pushing me to be on the go, and sitting still is a real struggle. Even when I'm forced to sit, I'm constantly tapping my feet or fidgeting with my hands under the table. When I try to talk to people, it feels like I'm reading a different script; I never know the right thing to say to keep the conversation going, and honestly, I'm not really all that interested in what my peers are up to anyway, so making friends is tough. It's like I miss all the little signals, you know, the way people move their hands or change their face to show what they mean – those just fly right over my head, and my own face probably doesn't show much either. I also find myself blurting things out because waiting my turn in a conversation feels impossible, and sometimes I just can't seem to figure out how to act "normal" in different places, like a quiet dinner versus a loud party. When things get too much, or even when I'm just really focused, I catch myself doing things like flapping my hands a bit or rocking back and forth. It's just how I am, always moving and always a bit out of sync with everyone else.

It feels like I'm always 'on the go,' like I've got a motor running inside me that just won't quit, and I often find myself getting up and wandering around even when I'm supposed to be sitting still, which makes quiet activities almost impossible. Even when I force myself to stay put, I'm always fidgeting or tapping my feet, and I just can't stand waiting my turn; I often blurt out answers or interrupt people mid-sentence because the words just burst out. This constant buzz means I struggle to focus on details, making careless mistakes all the time, and I frequently don't follow through on instructions, leaving projects half-done, which is made worse because I'm always losing important stuff I need to finish things and my attention drifts during tasks. My mind often seems to be elsewhere, so I don't really 'hear' people when they talk directly to me, and honestly, I don't really get how to do that back-and-forth conversation thing, or why people want to share all their feelings; making friends with other kids my age feels like a chore, not something fun. Any change to my routine or schedule, even something small, totally throws me off; I absolutely need things to happen exactly the way I expect, down to how things are said, following specific verbal patterns. What I *do* care about are my collections of old train schedules; I can spend hours just sorting them, mesmerized by the fonts and numbers, often spinning the little wheels on my toy train carriages over and over again. And sometimes, the energy just builds up so much that I'll run about or climb in places where it's totally inappropriate, without even thinking about it.

My brain feels like a racecar with no brakes, constantly 'on the go' and driven by a motor; I just can't sit still, often leaving my seat even when I'm supposed to be quiet, and it's impossible for me to engage in leisure activities quietly. Because of this, I often find it incredibly hard to focus on tasks or play, getting easily distracted by every little thing, and honestly, I avoid anything that needs me to really concentrate and usually don't follow through on instructions or finish anything I start. In conversations, I talk excessively, blurting out answers before questions are even done, and I just can't wait my turn, constantly interrupting or barging in. I don't really get the back-and-forth of talking, and people say my face doesn't show much, or I don't use many gestures, which makes making friends hard because I'm not really that interested in other kids my age; honestly, I find it tough to share emotions or even make eye contact. I also tend to say the same phrases over and over, or use really specific words, and I definitely have my routines that can't be messed with. Forget make-believe play; I'd rather spend hours just spinning the wheels on my toy cars or lining up my action figures, obsessed with tiny parts of them. And sometimes, I don't even notice if I hurt myself, almost like I don't feel pain the same way, but I do flap my hands when I get really excited or overwhelmed. Oh, and I'm always losing my stuff, like my keys or homework, and just generally forgetful about daily tasks.

My life often feels like I'm trying to navigate a crowded room blindfolded; it's really tough for me to figure out how to make friends or keep conversations going because I just don't get most social signals like eye contact or hand gestures. I tend to blurt out answers before people even finish talking and just talk and talk, sometimes totally missing what someone said to me directly because my mind drifts. My body's just as busy as my brain; I can't stay put for long, constantly getting up even when I'm supposed to be seated, and I'm always on the go, like I have a motor running inside, which means quiet activities are a no-go for me. This 'driven by a motor' thing spills into everything, leading to me making careless mistakes, being super forgetful in daily tasks, and constantly losing my keys or important papers. But then there are my interests; I can spend hours, days even, on my model train collection or researching ancient Roman plumbing systems – it's like a hyper-focused tunnel where everything else fades, and I get really attached to specific inanimate objects, like my worn-out coffee mug. The world can feel overwhelming too; certain loud noises or scratchy clothes send me through the roof, but then other times, I won't even notice if I've cut myself or touched something super hot. It's a constant battle between my need for rigid order and this internal chaos that makes me constantly interrupt people, even when I know I should wait my turn, making it really hard to connect with anyone my age and struggling with the give-and-take of a normal conversation.

Socially, I just don't get it; I struggle to read people's faces or gestures, and trying to follow the natural back-and-forth of a conversation is like trying to catch smoke. This makes it super hard to make or keep friends, and I often feel clueless about what's okay or not okay to do in different social situations, sticking to my own rigid ways of thinking and talking, sometimes repeating phrases. Any little change in my schedule or routine sends me into a tailspin; even if it's tiny, I get so upset, feeling a desperate need for things to stay exactly the same. I'm also really into specific things, like how I can spend hours just looking at the gears of an old clock, completely obsessed, rather than playing make-believe with anyone. And topping it all off, I'm just incredibly forgetful in daily activities, constantly needing reminders for everything.

My mind is always buzzing, like I'm driven by a motor that never turns off, which makes it super hard to just sit down and focus on one thing for long. My desk is usually a disaster zone because I really struggle with organizing tasks and just keeping things in order. Honestly, making friends has always been tough; I don't really get how to start or keep up those social relationships, and I'm not really all that interested in what other kids my age are doing. When people talk, I often miss the back-and-forth, sometimes interrupting or just not knowing what to say next, and I definitely don't pick up on all those subtle hand movements or facial expressions everyone else seems to understand. I guess my play is different too; I'd rather spend ages lining up my cars or just spinning their wheels, rather than pretending they're flying spaceships. And don't even get me started on routines – if something changes, even a tiny bit, I get totally thrown off because I need things to happen exactly the way I expect. Funny thing is, I barely notice if I scrape my knee or bump my head; it’s like I just don’t feel pain the same way.

Honestly, my life feels like it's running on fast-forward with no pause button; there's this constant hum inside me, like I'm always 'on the go' and driven by a motor that won't shut off. Even when I'm supposed to be still, I find myself needing to run about or fidget, making it tough to stay put. This internal rush often means I blurt out answers before questions are finished and constantly interrupt people without meaning to, which I know can be annoying. And when someone talks directly to me, it's like their words just pass right through; I don't seem to listen, and my mind often wanders. Organizing anything is a huge struggle, so my tasks and duties rarely get finished, leaving a trail of half-done projects. On top of all that, any minor change in my routine or schedule throws me into total distress because I really stick to my patterns and rituals. Socially, I just don't get it; I have a really hard time understanding people and making friends, plus I know my face doesn't show much emotion, and my eye contact is usually off. Sometimes, all the noise or certain fabric textures just overwhelm me, making me feel like my skin is crawling, and when things get too much, I'll start rocking or flapping my hands without even realizing it. It's just a lot to manage, trying to navigate a world that doesn't quite fit my brain.

My brain feels like it's always running a million miles an hour; I just can't sit still for long, often having to get up even when I'm supposed to stay put, and sometimes I even end up running around inappropriately because I feel so restless. People often talk directly to me, but it's like their words just float past because I don't seem to listen, making it really hard to keep my attention on boring tasks or wait my turn in conversations. Instead, I'd rather spend hours lining up my toy cars or just spinning their wheels, finding a weird kind of calm in that, which often means I can't even play quietly. If anyone tries to change my routine, like making me take a different route to school, it's a huge deal and really upsets me, almost like my whole world is off-kilter. When I get really overwhelmed or excited, I'll start flapping my hands without even realizing it, and I sometimes have to say things in a very specific, ritualized way. This constant internal drive and need for extreme predictability makes developing, understanding, and maintaining social relationships incredibly tricky.

It's tough for me to just chill out and do something quietly, like reading a book or watching TV; I always feel like I need to be up and doing something, moving around, even when I'm supposed to be relaxing. My brain just won't switch off, and if there's any little noise or movement around me, my focus is gone in an instant. It's like a whole language I just don't speak, which can make things a bit awkward. I try my best, but sometimes it feels like I'm playing a game with rules I don't quite grasp.

My brain feels like a broken radio, constantly tuning into static, making it impossible to stick to one thing; I just can't keep my attention on tasks, and forgetfulness is a daily struggle as I'm always losing my stuff and struggle to get anything organized. My life feels like a constant battle between needing everything to be just so, and my brain refusing to cooperate. My brain feels like it's always buzzing, making it impossible to just sit still, whether I'm at school or even trying to eat dinner; I'm constantly getting up and moving around. My head feels like a constant scramble; I'm always misplacing my wallet or keys and forgetting important stuff like doctor's appointments. My brain feels like a hundred tabs open at once; I'm constantly getting sidetracked by any little thing happening around me, or even just a random thought. My head is always buzzing, jumping from one thing to another, and it's tough for me to really listen when people talk directly; my mind just drifts, and then I often don't even finish what I started because I got distracted. Any tiny change to my routine, like a different route to the store, sends me into a spiral of anxiety, and loud noises or certain fabrics feel like sandpaper on my skin. When I'm really overwhelmed, I'll start flapping my hands or rocking back and forth, and sometimes I won't even notice if I cut myself, which freaks other people out. It’s like my brain works on a very specific set of verbal patterns and rules, and if anything deviates, even a simple figure of speech, it just doesn't compute, leaving me utterly confused.

My daily life feels like trying to herd cats – everything is a mess, and I constantly struggle with organizing tasks and activities. I'll make a list, but then I'm off doing something else entirely, often forgetting what I was meant to be doing. It’s not just my brain that's buzzing; my body can't keep still either. I'm always fidgeting, tapping my foot, or squirming in my seat, especially when I have to sit still for too long. And when I finally do get a chance to talk, I often talk excessively, sometimes without realizing I'm even doing it. This means I usually end up interrupting people or just rambling on and on. It’s genuinely hard to follow the natural back-and-forth of a conversation when my mind is racing like that. Plus, I have these pretty rigid ways of thinking; I'll get stuck on a particular phrase or way of explaining something, and it's tough for me to switch gears. It makes social interactions pretty exhausting, honestly.

My body always feels like it's got a motor running; I can't stay still and I'm constantly fidgeting with my hands or tapping my foot, which probably explains why I talk so much, often blurting out answers before questions are done and struggling to wait my turn, often interrupting folks. Because of this, making friends feels like trying to speak a foreign language I don't understand, and honestly, I'm not really all that interested in hanging out with kids my own age anyway. Instead, I prefer spending hours talking about my collection of antique train models, using the same detailed phrases to describe each piece – they're just so much more predictable than people. Any tiny change in my day, even a different route to school or a sudden plan switch, sends me into a complete tailspin; I just can't deal with things not going exactly as expected, and moving from one activity to another is like pulling teeth. And don't even get me started on sounds; a loud siren or even certain clothing textures can feel like a physical assault, it's just too much for my brain to handle.

My brain feels like a dozen browser tabs open at once; I can't really focus on one thing and I'm always getting sidetracked by little noises or just whatever pops into my head. Honestly, I talk a lot, and I know I jump in and interrupt people all the time because my thoughts just spill out. It's also hard to sit still; I usually end up getting up and walking around, even if I'm supposed to be seated, unless I'm totally zoned into my collection of antique doorknobs – I just love turning them over and feeling the weight. I can get so focused on those things that I barely notice if I bump into something hard or even cut myself; it just doesn't register sometimes. It's like my own unique operating system, making daily life a pretty wild ride that's tough for others to understand.

It's not just the running; they're constantly fidgeting, tapping their feet, or sometimes even doing this weird hand-flapping thing, especially when they get excited about one of their special interests, like endlessly lining up their toy cars and just spinning the wheels. These fixated interests are super intense, and they can talk about them for ages, but try to talk about anything else, or get them interested in playing with other kids, and they just switch off. They don't really get how to chat back and forth, and they totally miss things like knowing when to use gestures or even picking up on simple social cues, so they act pretty much the same no matter where we are. And don't even get me started on changes; if our routine gets messed up, it's a huge meltdown, but strangely, they don't seem to notice if they get a little cut or bump themselves hard, like they don't feel pain the same way.

My life often feels like I'm constantly running on high, like there's a motor inside me that just won't quit, and I'm always needing to move. This makes it impossible for me to just sit still, whether it's in a meeting or just trying to chill out at home; I can't really engage in quiet leisure activities because I'm always fidgeting or needing to do something. And when I'm with people, I often blurt things out or jump into what someone else is saying without thinking, totally interrupting them, because waiting my turn just feels excruciating. Because my mind is always racing and jumping, it's a nightmare to focus on boring stuff, so I keep putting off any task that needs real brain power, and I rarely actually finish instructions or get through my to-do list. This constant chaos means I'm always losing my keys or important papers, making everything even more frustrating. Socially, things are just as tough; I really struggle to figure out how to act in different situations, and I can't seem to make or keep friends because I just don't get the unspoken rules or how to really connect with people. Any little change in my routine or schedule throws me into a tailspin; I get really upset if things aren't exactly how I expect them to be, and I stick to these specific patterns because they make sense to me. Instead of make-believe, I'd rather spend hours obsessing over the mechanics of old clocks, maybe spinning their gears over and over, and sometimes I find myself repeating certain phrases without even realizing it. And don't even get me started on sounds or certain fabric textures; sometimes they just feel unbearable, like a physical attack.

Honestly, my days often feel like a chaotic mess, a constant tug-of-war between my mind flying off in a million directions and a deep need for everything else to be rigidly predictable. I can hardly ever sustain attention on a boring task because the slightest noise, like the faint hum of the office lights, or even just my own thoughts, instantly pulls my focus away. This means I frequently lose important papers and keys, and I definitely avoid tasks that require a lot of sustained mental effort, preferring to just put them off entirely. Even when I try to concentrate, I'm always fidgeting with my hands or tapping my foot, feeling like I'm driven by a motor that never shuts off, constantly needing to move. Socially, it's a whole different ballgame; I find it really hard to adjust my behavior for different crowds, and I often blurt out answers before someone's even finished their question, which I know makes me seem rude. Waiting my turn in a conversation or a queue is a nightmare, and honestly, making friends or trying to connect with peers just feels overwhelming and not something I'm particularly interested in. My real passion is collecting antique compasses; I spend hours meticulously categorizing them, and I get truly upset if my favorite brass one isn't in its exact spot—it's more than just a hobby, it's like a part of me.

It's like I'm always on a different channel than everyone else. On top of that, everything feels too loud or too bright sometimes, especially in crowded places; the sounds just bombard me and make my skin crawl, or I'll get totally mesmerized by some pattern on the wall instead of listening. And I can never just sit still, you know? My leg is always bouncing, or I'm tapping my fingers on the table, constantly fidgeting. It drives my colleagues nuts in meetings, but I just can't help it; it's like I have this nervous energy bubbling up inside me. It's a constant struggle to just feel "normal" or "tuned in" to what's happening around me.

It's like he's got springs in his shoes; he just can't stay seated for more than a minute. It feels like he's in his own little world, not really connecting with others.

My mind feels like a million tabs open at once; I'm constantly 'on the go,' restless and can't sit still, often leaving my seat even when I shouldn't be. I find myself blurting out answers before questions are finished and talking excessively, often interrupting others because I just can't wait my turn. Any little noise or movement easily distracts me, making it impossible to give close attention to details, so I make careless mistakes and rarely follow through on instructions, leaving duties unfinished. But beneath all that chaos, there's a deep need for things to be exact: any minor change to my routine, like my specific blue cup not being there, causes excessive distress, and I struggle immensely with transitions between tasks. Making friends is tough because I don't really get how to start or keep conversations going, and honestly, other kids my age don't interest me; I don't understand imaginative play and struggle to adjust my behavior to suit social contexts. It's like living in two different worlds, one driven by an unstoppable motor and the other rigidly needing everything to be just so, making real connections with people super hard.

My brain feels like a browser with a hundred tabs open all the time; even a little hum from the fridge or a car horn outside can instantly pull my attention away when I'm trying to focus on something important. It's funny though, because sometimes I won't even notice if I've cut myself or if the water in the shower is scalding hot; I just don't register that kind of pain until much later, if at all. Then there's the talking part; I know it's rude, but I just can't help myself, I'm always jumping in and finishing people's sentences or blurting out my thoughts before they're done speaking. It causes a lot of frustration, both for me and for everyone around me, because it's like my brain is moving too fast for the rest of the world to keep up with, and trying to manage all these conflicting signals is just plain exhausting.

Because of that, I often find myself talking way too much, and before someone even finishes their question, I've already blurted out an answer, which often means I interrupt folks without meaning to. I also struggle to understand why certain behaviors are okay in some places but not others, and reading people's gestures or knowing when to use my own is like trying to solve a puzzle with half the pieces missing. This all makes work hard because I miss little details and make careless mistakes, even when I'm trying really hard to focus. The only time my attention really locks in is when it's about ancient Roman architecture – I can go on for hours about it, completely fixated – but if my routine changes even slightly, like a different bus route, I get super distressed. This means I'll often blurt out answers before someone finishes asking, or just talk over everyone because waiting my turn is ridiculously hard and I struggle to keep a conversation flowing naturally. Social interactions are a minefield; I really struggle to pick up on what people mean by their gestures or facial expressions, and I often mess up because I don't get the unwritten social rules. This makes it tough to make friends, and sometimes I'll even repeat phrases or words from earlier conversations without realizing it. The smallest change to my routine can throw my whole day off, I hate when plans switch up unexpectedly. And then there's the sensory stuff: certain sounds, like humming lights, are unbearable, and when I get stressed, I just have to flap my hands, but weirdly, I sometimes won't even notice if I've hurt myself. I much prefer to spend my time diving deep into my fascination with antique train engines, examining every cog and wheel, rather than dealing with confusing people.

My mind feels like a constant hurricane, a mix of speed and an urgent need for things to stay exactly the same. I'm always losing my keys or forgetting what I was supposed to do, and I'll start a task but rarely finish it, leaving a trail of half-done projects and careless mistakes. It's like I have a motor running inside me; I'm constantly fidgeting, tapping my feet, or getting up and moving around, even when I should be still, and when I talk, it's usually too much, just blurting things out and interrupting others. Social stuff is a real puzzle; I struggle to know what to say back and forth in a chat, and people sometimes look confused when I don't make eye contact or show much expression. It's hard for me to figure out how to act in different situations, and honestly, I don't really care much about making friends with kids my age anyway. I get really into certain things, like spinning objects or looking at just one part of them, and if I get excited or stressed, I might flap my hands, which feels calming. I really need my routines to be rigid; if something changes, it throws my whole day off, even though my desk is usually a chaotic mess because I can't organize anything. My attention is all over the place; it's nearly impossible for me to focus on one thing for long, unless it's one of my special interests.

My life often feels like I'm trying to juggle flaming chainsaws in a disco, especially when I have to deal with unexpected changes in my routine. The noise in public places, like that awful buzzing of the fluorescent lights, just assaults me, and I can't help but tap my foot like crazy under the table during meetings. Half the time, I've already blurted out the answer before someone's even finished asking the question, and I constantly mess up how I'm supposed to act in different situations, like talking about my dinosaur collection at a funeral. My brain just fixates on certain things, like the way the light catches the corner of this specific wooden block I always carry, and if I'm into a topic, like medieval armor, that's all I want to talk about, sometimes repeating the same facts over and over. At work, a fly buzzing by the window can completely derail my focus from a report, and before I even realize it, I'm up and pacing around the office, even when I'm supposed to be sitting still. This constant mental scramble means I make so many stupid, careless mistakes because I just can't seem to pay attention to the small print. It's like my brain has a mind of its own, constantly seeking out my special interests and getting overwhelmed by everything else, making daily life a real challenge.

My mind and body are just always on the go, like I've got a motor running inside me that never shuts off; I can't help but tap my foot constantly or fidget with whatever's nearby. This makes it super hard to focus, so when people talk to me directly, it often seems like I'm not listening because my brain has just drifted off to something else, and I can't sustain attention for long. Socially, it's a minefield; I really struggle with knowing what's appropriate to say or do in different situations, and I probably don't make much eye contact, plus my face doesn't really show what I'm feeling. It's tough trying to make friends because I just don't get the back-and-forth of conversation, and honestly, I'm just not that interested in most kids my age. What I *am* interested in is my collection of historical maps – I can spend hours researching battle routes and get really upset if I'm interrupted or if my routine for that research changes even a little bit. Any small change, like a different route to school or a sudden shift in plans, can send me into a real tailspin. Funny thing is, I barely notice if I cut myself, but a scratchy shirt can totally ruin my entire day.

My brain just doesn't stop; I'm constantly 'on the go' and feel like I'm driven by a motor, which makes it super hard to sit still, so I'm always leaving my seat even when I shouldn't be. This inner restlessness means I talk excessively and often blurt out answers before people even finish their questions, and waiting my turn in a conversation or a line is practically impossible. Because my mind is racing and easily distracted by every little thing, I make careless mistakes all the time and rarely manage to finish instructions or duties, often getting sidetracked from tasks and play. This constant internal chaos bumps up against my intense need for things to stay exactly the same; even a minor change in schedule or activity throws me into excessive distress, making transitions a nightmare. I'd much rather spend all my time focused on my specific, intense interests, like collecting vintage maps – I'm totally fixated on them, and I even have a favorite map that's more important to me than most people. Frankly, I find making friends really tough, and I'm just not that interested in playing or hanging out with other kids my age, especially since I don't get imaginative games. What's weird is, even if I get a cut or burn myself, I often don't even notice it right away, like my body just doesn't register the pain.

Honestly, social stuff has always been a puzzle for me; I just don't really get how to keep a conversation going or why people get so worked up over feelings, mine or theirs, and it's hard enough for me to even initiate a chat. But then, when I *am* talking, I usually end up blurting things out and cutting people off because I just can't wait for my turn. And don't even get me started on sitting still; I always feel this buzz inside, like I need to be up and moving, so I'm constantly leaving my seat, even in situations where everyone else is just chilling. Forget about trying to relax quietly; my brain just won't let me engage in any calm activities. The worst part is when my day gets thrown off by some tiny little change – like if my usual coffee shop is closed, it completely derails me, and I can't function for hours. I just need things to go exactly as planned, or it feels like my whole world is upside down.

Honestly, my mind is a whirlwind. I can never stick with one task for long, easily distracted by anything shiny or a noise outside, and my wife often says I don't even hear her when she's talking directly to me, which leads to me messing up important details and making careless mistakes at work. I just can't sit still; I'm always getting up and pacing, especially in those boring meetings. And when I do talk, I tend to ramble on and on, sometimes repeating the same phrases without realizing. Socially, it's always been a puzzle; I struggle to understand people and keep friendships going, which probably links back to how I never really 'got' imaginative play as a kid. My home life is a total mess because organizing anything feels impossible. I also have this thing where loud sounds or certain fabric textures drive me nuts, but then sometimes I don't even notice if I've cut myself or if it’s freezing outside. I guess I just need things to follow my own rigid patterns, otherwise my brain just shuts down, like when I get stuck watching the repetitive motion of a fan.

My mind is a bit of a whirlwind, especially in conversations where I often just blurt out an answer before someone even finishes their question. It’s not that I mean to be rude, but social situations are just confusing for me; I never really got how to adjust my behavior or what the 'unwritten rules' were. Even as a kid, I was never into make-believe games; I’d much rather spend hours carefully organizing my collection of bottle caps, fascinated by the tiny logos on each one. That kind of intense focus carries into my adult life, where my whole world often revolves around everything there is to know about medieval architecture – it’s pretty much all I want to talk about. Because of that, I sometimes struggle to keep a conversation going about anything else, and I'm not really good at sharing my own feelings or even asking about others' problems. My partner gets frustrated because if our dinner plans change last minute, or if my morning routine is disrupted, it throws my whole day into a tailspin, and I get really upset. It’s like my brain needs everything to be just so, perfectly predictable, otherwise it feels like the world is coming apart at the seams.

Honestly, I feel like I've got a motor running inside me all the time; I just can't sit still for long. It makes conversations tricky because my mind is always buzzing, and I struggle to keep up with the back-and-forth of what people are saying. It's like they're playing tennis and I'm watching a different game entirely, so I end up missing my turn to "hit the ball" back. What really calms me down is my collection of antique radios. I spend hours tinkering with them, polishing them, and sometimes I even talk to my favorite old Philco like it's a person. I know it sounds weird, but those radios understand me better than most people do. If someone tries to change the subject when I'm talking about vacuum tubes, I just sort of shut down. I don't mean to be rude, but my brain just doesn't know how to switch gears that fast for small talk.

Honestly, my mind is a whirlwind. I constantly put off anything that takes real brainpower, so I end up with a pile of half-finished projects and rarely follow through on instructions. Conversations are a nightmare; I struggle to keep up with the back-and-forth, often losing my place or just blabbing about my own thing. And speaking of blabbing, I have a terrible habit of interrupting people, unable to wait my turn because an idea just has to come out right now. When I'm not deep into my very specific obsession with antique clock mechanisms – I could talk about them for hours and get angry if someone tries to change the subject – I often find myself rocking back and forth or flapping my hands without even noticing. It's like my body and mind are on different tracks, each struggling in its own way.

My mind and body are always on overdrive; I feel like I'm constantly 'driven by a motor,' unable to stay still or even play quietly. This makes it impossible to focus on anything for long, so I often leave my seat during meetings, and my attention just flits away to any little sound or movement around me. People often get annoyed because it seems like I don't listen when they talk to me directly, but honestly, my brain is just too busy, which leads to me making a ton of careless mistakes and missing details in tasks that require real effort. When I do talk, I tend to talk excessively and blurt things out, often interrupting others because I just can't wait my turn to speak; the conversation feels less like a natural back-and-forth and more like a series of quick bursts. My face and body usually stay pretty neutral, so I guess I don't use many gestures or show a lot of expression, which makes it hard for people to read me. I also have this thing where I need things to be done a certain way, sticking to very specific verbal patterns or rituals in how I talk or think, and any change in my schedule or activity just throws me off completely. Sometimes, if I get overwhelmed by bright lights or loud noises, I'll start hand flapping or rocking back and forth to calm myself down, almost without realizing it. It's just a constant battle between my internal need for order and the chaos of everything else.

My brain feels like a dozen tabs open at once, making it incredibly hard to focus on one thing or keep anything organized, and I'm constantly getting pulled off track by every little sound or movement around me. Social situations are a minefield; I struggle to make friends or even understand what people mean with their weird facial expressions and hand gestures, and honestly, I'm just not that interested in playing make-believe. I'm always fidgeting, tapping my foot, or just feeling like I need to run around, making it tough to just sit still, and I even do this little hand-flapping thing when I'm really overwhelmed. Man, I swear I've got ants in my pants sometimes. I'm always tapping my foot under the table, or drumming my fingers, especially when I have to sit still for too long. If I'm in a meeting or a long class, you can bet I'll find an excuse to get up and move around a few times, because just sitting there feels impossible. People sometimes get annoyed because I'm always interrupting or finishing their sentences. My body just can't sit still; I'm always 'on the go,' buzzing like a motor even when I'm supposed to be relaxing. And you know, sometimes I don't even notice if I've gotten a small cut or bumped myself hard; I guess I just don't feel pain the same way everyone else does.

Honestly, social stuff is just baffling to me; I never quite know how to act in different situations or why certain things are okay at a party but not at work. I always miss what people mean when they make weird hand gestures, and my face doesn't always show what I'm feeling either, which means people often tell me I don't make enough eye contact. Honestly, my life feels like I'm constantly running a marathon, even when I'm just trying to relax; it's like I have this internal motor that just won't quit, always needing to move or do something. My brain feels like it's constantly running on two different speeds, and honestly, it makes life a total mess. I really struggle with understanding what people mean when they wave their hands around, or why they get upset when I just blurt out an answer without waiting for them to finish, which happens all the time. My day starts pretty much the same way every time, otherwise, I just can't function right. If my cereal bowl isn't the blue one, it throws everything off, and I get really upset. People always tell me I say the same things over and over, or I use weird phrases like 'affirmative, captain' instead of 'yes'. My brain just works in its own specific way, and I find it hard to change how I think or say things.

"People often tell me I just talk too much (SYMPTOM 1: Often talks excessively). Once I get going on a topic, it’s hard to stop. I've noticed I sometimes repeat the same few phrases over and over, almost like a loop (SYMPTOM 3: Repetitive use of phrases, echolalia, or idiosyncratic/rigid language), and I really struggle to keep up with the back-and-forth of conversations, often missing my turn or misunderstanding the flow (SYMPTOM 2: Deficits in the socio-communicative flow). At work, it’s a constant struggle; I can't seem to follow through on instructions and a lot of my duties end up unfinished (SYMPTOM 4: Does not follow through on instructions and fails to finish duties). I make so many careless mistakes because I just don't pay attention to the little details (SYMPTOM 5: Fails to give close attention to details or makes careless mistakes), and if a task needs a lot of brainpower, I'll always put it off or avoid it entirely (SYMPTOM 6: Avoids or is reluctant to engage in tasks requiring sustained mental effort). Growing up, I never really understood imaginative games; I preferred things that were factual and real (SYMPTOM 7: Deficits in imaginative or symbolic play, or absence of spontaneous social play). And oddly enough, I hardly ever notice when I've cut myself or if something is really hot or cold; it's like my body just doesn't register it properly (SYMPTOM 8: Hyporeactivity to pain/temperature, or unusual response to sensory input)."

My life often feels like a tornado in a library; I'm always on the go, like I'm driven by a motor, but I can never seem to organize my tasks or finish anything I start. I lose my keys, phone, or important papers all the time, and any little noise or movement can distract me easily, so it seems like I don't even hear you when you talk directly to me. Sitting still is a nightmare; I'm constantly fidgeting or tapping my feet, and if I'm not moving, I'm probably talking excessively or blurting out answers before anyone finishes their question. Social gatherings are tough; I never know what the right thing to do or say is, and I often struggle to make eye contact or show much expression on my face. I really don't get imaginative play, but I can spend hours just lining up my collection of vintage bottle caps or talking about the precise history of ancient coins, often repeating the same phrases or facts over and over. Any change in my routine, even a slight shift in my daily schedule, throws me completely off balance, and my thoughts follow such rigid patterns that it's hard to think outside the box. Sometimes I don't even notice if I've cut myself, but other times a loud noise or bright light feels like a physical attack; that's when I might start flapping my hands to try and calm down. It's just hard to sustain attention on things that aren't my special interests, and the idea of quiet leisure activities just doesn't compute with my restless energy.

My brain feels like it's always on overdrive; I can't just relax and do quiet things like reading, because I'm constantly restless, needing to run around even when it's not the right time. When it comes to schoolwork, I hate anything that needs me to really concentrate for a long time, so I always put off those big assignments. And honestly, even when I do start something, I rarely follow all the instructions or manage to actually finish it.

Honestly, my life feels like it's running on fast-forward with a broken social manual. It's funny, sometimes I don't even notice if I've cut myself, but a loud sound can send me through the roof.

Honestly, some days it feels like my brain just checks out when faced with anything that requires real focus; I'll put off that detailed report at work for weeks, just dreading the mental effort it demands. It's like everyone else is communicating with some secret code I don't have access to, making every interaction feel like a complicated puzzle. Honestly, my life sometimes feels like a constant struggle to keep up with what everyone else considers "normal." Honestly, my body just won't quit; I feel like I'm always 'on the go,' with a motor running inside me, even when I'm supposed to be still, which leads to me constantly fidgeting or tapping my foot.
