Any change in routine, even a small one like taking a different route to the store, throws me into a tailspin, and the world is just too loud and bright sometimes – certain fabrics feel like sandpaper, yet I barely notice if I cut myself. Trying to just relax or do a quiet activity is out of the question; my brain just won't let me.

My brain feels like it's constantly running at a million miles an hour, which makes it really hard to focus on just one thing or finish any boring task. I'm always 'on the go,' like I've got a motor inside me, so sitting still is a nightmare; I'm either fidgeting my feet under the table or I just have to get up and walk around, even in meetings. And I talk way too much, often blurting out answers before anyone finishes their question, which probably doesn't help when I'm already struggling to understand what people mean when they shrug or raise an eyebrow. Honestly, I'm just not great at adjusting my behavior for different situations; I'm pretty blunt, and people say my face doesn't show much emotion, and I don't really 'get' imaginative play, preferring to just spin my car tires over and over. Any small change in my daily schedule or a specific way I say things can really set me off, and I just can't stand it when my routine is broken. The hum of the lights or certain fabric textures drive me crazy, but oddly enough, sometimes I barely notice if I get a cut or burn myself. I feel restless all the time, like I could just start running around, and waiting for my turn, whether in a line or a conversation, feels physically impossible. Sometimes, when I'm really overwhelmed, I just start flapping my hands, which I know looks weird, but it's the only way to cope with this constant hurricane in my head.

My brain and body are in a constant battle; I'm always fidgeting or tapping my foot, and feel so restless that staying put, especially at work or school, is a monumental effort, often leading me to get up when I absolutely shouldn't. This chaotic energy also means I struggle to focus on anything boring, leading to careless mistakes and me constantly losing things like my keys or phone, and I often just zone out when someone's talking directly to me. Social interactions are a minefield; I interrupt people all the time, blurt out whatever comes to mind without waiting my turn, and then I completely miss the back-and-forth of the conversation, making me feel totally lost. I also never quite pick up on the unwritten rules for how to act in different situations, and I barely use or understand hand gestures, which probably explains why making friends feels impossible and I don't really bother with kids my age. When I get really stressed or super focused, I'll start flapping my hands or rocking, and I can spend ages just repeating actions with specific objects, like spinning a bottle cap, which helps me feel grounded. It’s also weird because I barely register pain if I cut myself, almost like I’m numb to it. My brain is full of incredibly specific interests, like memorizing every detail about ancient Roman coinage, and I get seriously upset if my routines change even slightly, or if I have to use different words than my usual rigid phrases. And don't even get me started on trying to relax or do anything quietly; it's just not in my nature.

My days pretty much run on a set track, and honestly, if anything changes, even a tiny shift in my morning routine or a last-minute plan, it totally throws me off and messes up my whole day. Honestly, my head often feels like a crowded room with everyone talking at once. And don't even think about changing my daily schedule; if my lunch isn't at precisely 12:30, it throws my entire afternoon off, making me super anxious. It's like my brain has a very specific operating manual, and any deviation causes a complete system overload.

My brain often feels like a browser with too many tabs open, which makes me constantly fail to give close attention to details and often leads to careless mistakes, especially when I'm trying to sustain attention on a boring task. So yeah, between not getting the pretend stuff, being constantly on the go, and barely feeling bumps and bruises, I guess I'm a bit different from most other kids.

My head feels like a busy highway most days, making simple stuff complicated. I'm always making dumb, careless mistakes at work, missing details because my brain just wants to rush to the next thing. Anything that needs me to really sit down and focus for a long time? Forget it; I'll find a million distractions before I even start. My partner often gets frustrated because it seems like I don't hear a word they're saying when they talk right to me, even though I'm trying. Then, when I'm out with friends, I tend to just talk and talk, barely taking a breath, and I'm really bad at waiting for my turn in a conversation, always jumping in. Even trying to relax is hard; I can't just sit still and quietly enjoy something. It's like I'm constantly driven by an internal motor that just won't shut off, making everything a bit of a challenge.

My brain never stops, and neither do my hands; I'm always tapping or squirming in my seat, like I've got an internal motor. It's really hard to just sit still, and I often feel this urge to run around or climb, even when it's totally not the right time for it. When I do talk, I just keep going and going, sometimes using the same strange phrases over and over, and I don't really get how to use my hands to explain things like other people do. Conversations are tough because I struggle to keep up with the natural back-and-forth, and honestly, I'm not that interested in what others are feeling or doing unless it's about my favorite topic, which is ancient Roman plumbing systems – I could talk about that for hours and don't really care if you're bored. I tend to miss details all the time and make silly mistakes because something shiny or a random thought will easily distract me. I don't really get pretend play or making up stories; I much prefer facts and clear information. Oh, and sometimes I don't even notice if I've bumped myself and gotten a bruise; it's like I just don't feel it.

My brain feels like a dozen browser tabs open at once; it's a real struggle to stay focused on one thing for too long, like trying to read a book while someone's constantly yelling "Look at this!" Because of this, I often find myself leaving tasks unfinished or avoiding anything that needs deep concentration, and honestly, keeping my stuff organized feels like an impossible puzzle. Physically, I'm always on the go; my foot is usually tapping, or I'm fidgeting with my hands, and I find it impossible to just sit still or do anything quietly. Sometimes, when I'm really overwhelmed or deep in thought, I'll find myself flapping my hands or walking on my tiptoes without even realizing it. My comfort zone is my obsession with collecting and categorizing rare mineral samples; I'm intensely fixated on their crystalline structures and can spend hours examining tiny facets, getting pretty upset if my schedule or how I display them is messed with.

My mind is a whirlwind, and it makes every day a constant uphill battle. It truly feels like my brain is running on two different speeds, causing chaos for both me and those around me.

My life often feels like a constant battle between a racing mind that can't focus and a rigid brain that needs everything exactly so. Because of all this, making and keeping friends is really tough, and sometimes I find myself repeating certain phrases or words over and over without realizing it, especially if I'm feeling overwhelmed or trying to stick to my strict routines. My brain feels like it's always buzzing with a million thoughts at once. I often get told off because when someone talks to me directly, it's like their voice just floats past me; I just don't seem to listen, especially if I'm thinking about my trains. My model train collection is my entire world, and I can spend hours just sorting the miniature signals and tracks, lost in my own thoughts. This deep dive into my trains means that other stuff, like chores or even keeping track of appointments, just flies out of my head – I'm constantly forgetting important things. It's so hard to focus on anything else for long; my mind just drifts off to my next train project. Even when I'm supposed to be sitting still, my hands are always tapping, or my foot is going a mile a minute under the table. That specific, old brass whistle, the one that came with my very first engine, is super important to me, and I can't imagine anyone touching it. It's like I have two different brains: one for my trains, and one for everything else that just struggles to keep up.

My brain feels like it's always running on fast forward, but also getting stuck. It's tough to just sit still; I'm constantly tapping my foot or squirming in my chair, and if I have to do something boring, like paperwork, I'll avoid it forever and usually lose the forms anyway. And don't even get me started on routines! If my schedule changes even a little, or if we have to transition to a new activity, it throws my whole day into a tailspin. It makes me super anxious, and I might start rocking back and forth or flapping my hands to try and calm down. My family says I always have to follow these specific rules, like using certain phrases or doing things in an exact order, and it’s like my thoughts are stuck in those patterns. Social stuff is a whole other mess: I'm not really interested in making friends my age, and honestly, I don't get why they play pretend games. When people talk, I often zone out completely, and it's like their words just don't stick; I have a hard time waiting for my turn in conversations, so I just blurt things out, and I probably don't make much eye contact or show what I'm feeling on my face. I really struggle to understand what others are feeling or how to join in a give-and-take conversation, and I often miss the unspoken rules of how to act in different situations. Instead, I'd rather spend hours looking at how specific gears work in old clocks – the tick-tock sounds don't bother me, but a sudden loud noise can send me through the roof; it's also really hard for me to organize my day, and I might suddenly get up and walk around the room during a meeting if I can't stay still.

My son is a whirlwind; it feels like he's always 'on the go' and can't sit still for a second, even when we try to do something quiet like reading. He'll be doing his homework, and then a bird outside, or even just a dust mote, completely pulls his attention away. You can talk directly to him, and it's like he doesn't even hear you. His room is a constant disaster, and he loses everything—his backpack, shoes, favorite toys—all the time. Trying to get him to finish any task or follow instructions is a nightmare because he makes so many careless mistakes and rushes through things. He constantly blurts things out and interrupts me or anyone else talking. Making friends has always been tough; he just doesn't seem all that interested in kids his own age, and he struggles with knowing how to join a conversation or keep it going. And sometimes he'll just stare blankly or avoid eye contact when you're talking to him, and his face rarely shows what he's feeling. He also doesn't really use hand gestures to explain things, and doesn't get why certain things are okay in one situation but not another. What he really cares about are trains – he can spend hours just lining up his train cars perfectly, and when he gets excited or overwhelmed, he'll start flapping his hands. It's strange, but sometimes he won't even notice if he scrapes his knee pretty badly, and heaven forbid we try to change his routine or switch to a new activity unexpectedly; that usually leads to a big meltdown.

My brain feels like a dozen browser tabs open at once, constantly fighting for attention, making it incredibly hard to focus on one thing and easily distracted by anything; this means I rarely finish tasks or follow instructions, and my desk is a disaster zone because I just can't seem to organize anything properly. I'm also terribly forgetful about daily stuff, like where I put my keys or important appointments. Physically, I'm always restless; I'm constantly fidgeting, tapping my feet, and sometimes I just have to get up and pace around, even if it's completely inappropriate for the situation. Trying to do anything quietly is a real struggle, and I often interrupt people, blurting out answers before they're done speaking. Socially, things are a mess; I struggle to follow what's going back and forth in a chat, and I never really know what to do with my hands or how my face should look when someone's talking seriously. I'm not really interested in developing friendships, and honestly, sharing emotions or understanding others' feelings just doesn't come naturally to me, making it hard to adjust my behavior to different social situations. I never really got into imaginative play as a kid; I was always more fascinated with the tiny gears of a toy or lining up my cars perfectly, or just watching their wheels spin. My mind tends to get stuck on rigid patterns of thinking, and even a small change in my daily schedule can throw me into absolute panic or distress, like I have to do certain things in a specific order. Another odd thing is how I handle pain; sometimes I don't even notice if I've cut myself or touched something really hot. On top of everything, I often rock back and forth or flap my hands when I'm stressed or excited; it's just something my body does.

Any change to my routine, like a different route to school or if my dinner time is off, totally throws me for a loop; I have real difficulties with transitions. Because of this constant motor feeling, I often end up leaving my seat when I'm supposed to stay put, or even feel like running or climbing when it's totally inappropriate, even if I just feel that internal restlessness. And sometimes, it’s weird, but I don't even notice if I've gotten a cut or bumped myself hard; it's like I'm a bit indifferent to pain sometimes.

My life feels like I'm running on triple speed; I'm always 'on the go' like I'm driven by a motor, constantly feeling restless and needing to move, often fidgeting in my seat or just up and out of it when everyone else is supposed to stay put. My mind jumps around so much that I often talk excessively, sometimes even when people are talking to me, but then it's like I don't seem to listen because my attention just drifts away; I'm super forgetful in daily activities, always misplacing things. This makes it really hard to follow the natural back-and-forth of a conversation, and I struggle to make friends my age because I just don't get the social norms or why I should even bother trying to adjust myself for different groups. I guess that's partly why I have my own ways of doing things, like needing to stick to certain routines, and I get really upset by even minor changes; I also tend to use the same phrases over and over sometimes, or have these really intense interests, like the history of lighthouses, where I can talk for hours about it. When I'm really deep into one of my topics, I might find myself flapping my hands, and I've noticed I don't always react much to getting a cut or if something's really hot or cold, which my mom finds weird. I can also just stare at the gears of a clock, or the way a specific part of a toy moves, for ages, totally focused. It's all a bit of a whirlwind, trying to navigate a world that doesn't quite make sense to my brain.

My brain feels like a broken TV constantly flipping channels; it's so hard to keep my mind on one thing, especially if it's boring, and even if someone's talking directly to me, it often feels like their words just bounce off. I'm always restless, needing to move, so sitting still is a nightmare; I often leave my seat, or just feel like running around, and in conversations, I can't help but blurt out answers or interrupt, struggling to wait my turn. My life is a constant mess because organizing anything feels impossible, and I'm always forgetting appointments or losing my stuff, like my keys or important papers. What really grabs me are specific things, like how a fan motor spins, or collecting every single model car, and I can spend hours just focusing on that with an intense, almost obsessive interest. When I get excited or stressed, I tend to flap my hands a lot or rock back and forth, and honestly, I never really got the point of pretend play or playing with other kids; it just doesn't make sense to me. Because of all this, making friends is really hard, and I'm not that interested in hanging out with others my age, especially if there's any small change to my routine, which can really upset me and throw my whole day off.

My life often feels like I'm operating on a different wavelength than everyone else. My body also has a mind of its own; I just can't sit still for long, especially in places where you're supposed to stay put, like long meetings or waiting rooms. What's even stranger is that I barely register pain – I've scraped myself pretty bad or touched something hot and just sort of shrugged it off, only realizing the extent of it later. It's like my system doesn't quite process sensory stuff the way it should, adding to the general confusion.

I've always found imaginative play difficult, preferring instead to immerse myself in my fixed interests, like collecting specific types of old keys, often fascinated by just one small part of them, instead of inventing stories. This deep focus means I often lose important things needed for tasks or am generally forgetful in daily activities because my mind is elsewhere. Any tiny shift in my rigid routine or verbal patterns can cause me immense distress, and I'm hyper-aware of everything around me due to my hypersensitivity to sounds and textures. When things get too much, I sometimes find myself rocking or hand-flapping, almost without thinking, just to cope with the overload.

My brain sometimes feels like a tangled ball of yarn; I just can't seem to get a grip on organizing tasks and activities, so my desk is always a disaster. People tell me I talk excessively, sometimes even when they're trying to talk to me, and then they say I don't seem to listen when spoken to directly, but my mind is just buzzing. I've always struggled with social situations, never really understanding how to just 'play' with others or what all those hand gestures mean; it's like a secret language I don't speak. Don't even get me started on changes; if my schedule shifts, it throws my whole day off balance, and I just can't handle those difficulties with transitions. Plus, I'm always on the go, like I'm driven by a motor, even when I'm supposed to be relaxing. It's exhausting trying to keep up with myself sometimes.

My mind feels like a thousand tabs open at once; I'm always fidgeting or tapping my foot, even during meetings, and forget things like my keys constantly. I struggle to keep my focus on any one thing for long, getting easily sidetracked by any little sound, and this means I often miss details and make careless mistakes, especially with instructions. This makes organizing my day a nightmare, and I end up talking excessively and interrupting people all the time, blurting things out before they finish, which definitely doesn't help me make friends. I often find myself running around or climbing things when I really shouldn't, and when someone tries to talk to me directly, it's like my brain just doesn't register it, leaving them thinking I'm not listening. The whole back-and-forth of conversations is tricky for me; I don't really get how to fit in with other people my age, and honestly, imaginative games never made much sense, preferring to collect facts about vintage train schedules. My language can be a bit rigid sometimes, like repeating certain phrases, and I get really upset if my antique compass isn't exactly where I left it on my desk, feeling barely anything if I accidentally nick myself with it. Any tiny change to my routine, even a different route to the store, causes huge distress, and when I'm stressed, I often find myself rocking back and forth or flapping my hands, which I know looks odd. It's like I have a hard time understanding the unwritten rules for different social situations, so I often adjust my behavior poorly, unintentionally coming across wrong to others.

My mind feels like a constant scramble; I’m always losing my keys or forgetting what I was supposed to do today. If someone tries to tell me something directly, I probably won't hear them because my brain is already off on another tangent, easily distracted by anything around me. I really hate tasks that need me to sit still and focus for a long time; I'll put those off forever. Instead, I'd rather be playing with my car collection, lining them up perfectly and just staring at the wheels spinning for hours – it's all I want to do. Socializing is tough; I don't really get why people do it, and I'm not good at making friends or sharing how I feel, and my face probably shows it. Plus, I often interrupt people, blurt out answers, and just can't keep quiet because I talk excessively, which makes conversations awkward. My body is always moving too; I feel restless and often tap my foot or fidget, and sometimes I even flap my hands without realizing it – I definitely can't do quiet activities. Don't even get me started on changes to my schedule; if my bus route is different, it throws my whole day off, and I get really upset, sticking rigidly to my specific ways of doing things and even using the same odd phrases. Honestly, organizing things is a nightmare, and I barely notice if I cut myself because I'm so focused on my own world.

My life feels like a constant scramble; I'm always losing my phone or wallet, and honestly, half the time I can't even remember what I was supposed to do today, let alone where I put my keys. Trying to get things organized? Forget about it. My desk is a disaster zone, and I just can't seem to get my head around planning out tasks for work or even just sorting out my errands. And talking to people can be a minefield. I'm usually so excited or have an idea popping into my head that I just blurt out the answer before they've even finished their sentence, which I know makes me seem rude. It's not just that; I often say things that don't quite fit the situation, or I miss why someone got offended, because I just don't get those unwritten social rules everyone else seems to know. Plus, my mind is always bouncing around; a bird outside the window or a tiny noise can completely pull my focus away from whatever I'm meant to be concentrating on. The only time my brain really locks in is when I'm deep into studying ancient Roman engineering; I can spend hours researching aqueducts and forgotten construction methods, ignoring everything else around me, and I find it impossible to stop once I'm started. Funnily enough, even if I get a bad cut while working on something, I often don't notice the pain until much later, almost like my body doesn't register it right away.

Man, I feel like I've got a motor running inside me constantly; sitting still is practically impossible, and I'm always fidgeting or needing to get up and move around. Because of that, I often blurt things out or just jump into conversations because I find it super hard to wait my turn, which probably makes me seem rude. Sometimes, when my mom is trying to tell me something, I'll just be staring right through her, and she says I don't seem to listen at all. It's not that I don't care, it's just my brain is usually buzzing with thoughts about medieval siege weapons – I can spend hours researching every little detail, and it’s truly the most important thing. I often catch myself saying 'It is what it is' over and over when I'm stressed, or using really specific historical terms even when they don't quite fit. And don't even get me started on changes; if my usual route to the library is blocked, or if dinner isn't at the exact time, it feels like my whole world just goes sideways. I really struggle to switch gears from one thing to another, especially if it means tearing myself away from my research, and it gets me pretty worked up.

Honestly, my brain just won't settle down. I find it nearly impossible to really focus on one thing, whether it's homework or even just a fun game; my attention just jumps to something else after a few minutes. And 'quiet' isn't really in my vocabulary when it comes to leisure; I'm always moving, tapping, or making some kind of noise, like I've got this constant buzz inside me. You'll often see me rocking back and forth or even flapping my hands a bit when I'm really excited or feeling overwhelmed, it just sort of happens on its own. It's not a conscious choice, it's just how my body deals with things. Plus, any little thing – a bird outside the window, someone clearing their throat, even a flickering light – can totally pull my focus away and then I've lost my train of thought completely. It makes getting anything done a real struggle.

Honestly, social stuff has always been a puzzle for me; it's why making friends and keeping them is so hard. People often tell me I don't make eye contact, or that my face is just blank, even when I'm excited, which I guess counts as not using many gestures either. When someone talks directly to me, it's like their words just float away – I sometimes don't seem to listen, even though I'm trying to process everything. Then, I tend to blurt out what I'm thinking, interrupting people without meaning to, or I'll catch myself repeating a funny phrase I heard earlier over and over. I can't stand loud noises or scratchy clothes; they just overwhelm me, and sometimes I just stare at patterns or the flickering lights for ages. My day has to go exactly as planned, too; if my usual bus route changes, it completely throws me off and makes me super anxious. It's like I have these very specific ways of talking and doing things, and if anything shifts, it's a disaster.

I just don't get the whole social dance; people make all these faces and hand movements, but it's like a secret code I can't crack, which makes having proper conversations or even friends really tough. And then, to make it worse, I often just blurt things out or go on and on, totally interrupting whoever is speaking and probably boring them to death. My mind is always racing, which means my desk is usually a disaster area, and trying to plan anything feels like trying to herd cats. I'll rush through work and miss crucial details, making stupid mistakes, and I swear my keys and phone have a personal vendetta against me because I'm always losing them. I'm pretty set in my ways too; if my routine gets messed up or someone tries to change how I do things, even small stuff, it just throws my whole day off. What I really love, though, is just watching how things work, like the intricate gears in a clock or how a certain material catches the light; I could spend ages just looking at it. It’s weird, but sometimes I don't even notice if I've bumped myself pretty hard or gotten a minor cut, like my body just doesn't register it right away.

My kid's day usually starts in a whirlwind; he can barely focus on breakfast, constantly getting sidetracked by anything shiny, and it feels like he never really listens when I'm talking directly to him. Getting ready is a nightmare because he makes careless mistakes like putting shoes on the wrong feet, and we’re always losing important stuff, which means we're constantly late, and he rarely follows through on instructions or finishes his homework. He just can't sit still for a minute; he's constantly fidgeting, tapping his feet, or squirming, and even when we try to do something relaxing, like reading, he's unable to play or engage quietly, often running about or climbing on furniture. In conversations, it's a constant struggle; he talks excessively and just can't wait his turn, always interrupting or blurting things out, completely derailing the flow. It's like he misses all the social cues; his facial expressions are pretty flat, he barely makes eye contact, and he doesn't use gestures to show he understands, which makes it hard for others to read him. He also tends to use the same phrases over and over, sometimes out of context, and when he gets excited, he'll start flapping his hands, especially if he's talking about his trains – he's obsessed with collecting old train schedules and has a weird attachment to a specific toy caboose. Loud noises or certain clothes drive him crazy, making him shut down, and any sudden change in our daily routine or even just switching from one activity to another throws him into a complete meltdown, it's just so hard for him to adapt. He’s not really interested in making friends with other kids, preferring to be by himself, and when it comes to schoolwork, he avoids tasks that require him to really focus his brain for a long time, often forgetting what he needs to do for the next day.

My mind feels like a million tabs open at once, constantly jumping from one thing to another, and I often miss details or make dumb mistakes because I'm so easily sidetracked by any little noise or thought. My life often feels like a constant struggle because I can never get my tasks organized; my desk is always a disaster, and I'm always making careless mistakes because my mind just jumps ahead. When I'm in a conversation, I jump in too fast, blurting out answers before anyone finishes their question, and then I just keep talking, making it really tough to follow the natural back-and-forth or figure out when it's actually my turn. Social situations are a minefield because I just don't get the unspoken rules, which makes it hard to adjust my behavior, and honestly, I don't really bother with making a lot of friends. Any small change to my daily routine, like a different route to work, completely throws me off, and I have very specific ways I like things to be said, almost like a ritual. I'd much rather be immersed for hours in my deep fascination with old nautical charts or examining every tiny detail of my antique compass collection, which I'm unusually attached to, than deal with people. It's impossible for me to sit quietly for anything; I always feel this restless energy buzzing inside me. Sometimes I'll cut myself or burn my hand and barely notice it until much later; my body just doesn't seem to register pain the same way.

My mind is a whirlwind; I'm constantly losing my keys or phone and forgetting appointments. It's a miracle I get anything done because I make so many careless mistakes and often get sidetracked by any little thing, leaving tasks half-finished. It’s like I have a motor running inside me; I can’t sit still for a minute without tapping my foot or needing to get up and move around, unable to engage in quiet leisure. This constant motion makes conversations tough, as I often blurt out answers or interrupt before people finish talking, and waiting my turn is a nightmare, plus I talk way too much, totally missing the natural back-and-forth; honestly, people often say I don't seem to listen when they're speaking to me directly. It's hard for me to make friends or even care much about other kids my age, and I just don't get the whole give-and-take of sharing emotions or interests; I guess I don't really know how to adjust what I'm doing in different social situations, and developing and keeping relationships just seems so difficult. What really holds my attention are things like sorting my collection of old coins, obsessed with every tiny detail, or just spinning a specific part of a toy for ages; when I'm excited or stressed, I might flap my hands, which I know looks weird, and sometimes I'll repeat the same phrases over and over. Loud noises or certain clothes drive me absolutely crazy, but sometimes I don't even notice if I get a cut or burn myself. God forbid my routine changes even slightly, like a different route to school or a sudden change in plans; it throws my whole day into a complete meltdown.

My son, Leo, is a whirlwind, constantly on the go; it's like he's got a motor inside, often running about or climbing even when it's totally inappropriate. Trying to get him to focus on anything, even his favorite game, is nearly impossible because his attention just scatters in seconds. You can talk directly to him, but it's like he doesn't even hear you; he just tunes out completely. He always has trouble waiting his turn for anything, whether it's a game or just talking, and he'll blurt out answers or interrupt before you've even finished your question. It's a constant struggle to keep track of his things; he loses his jacket, his toys, his schoolwork – you name it. The weirdest thing is sometimes he'll get a scrape or bump and barely flinch, almost like he's indifferent to the pain or temperature. Socially, he struggles a lot; he doesn't seem to understand how to make or keep friends, and he's not really interested in imaginative play with other kids his age. And if we ever have to change our routine, even something small like a different route to the store, he gets incredibly distressed, needing everything to be just so.

My mind is always racing; I'm constantly fidgeting in my seat, tapping my feet, and sometimes I just have to get up and pace around the room because I feel this restless energy inside me, even when it's totally inappropriate. It’s a nightmare trying to keep my stuff together; I’m always losing my keys or my phone, and organizing any task or activity feels like trying to herd cats – everything gets mixed up and I can't keep track. Conversations are a trip; I often blurt out answers before people even finish asking, and I talk so much that I end up interrupting everyone or just taking over because I can’t seem to wait my turn, which probably explains why I have trouble making friends and don't really get how to share emotions back and forth. I also just don't pick up on hints, like when someone changes their facial expression or uses a gesture; it's like a different language I don't speak, and I often use weird phrases or sound really formal and rigid without meaning to, which makes the whole back-and-forth flow of talking super hard for me. Small changes really throw me off; if my routine for getting ready is even slightly different, or if my bus route changes, it feels like a total meltdown, because I need things to be exactly the same, following my own set of unbendable rules and rigid thinking patterns. I guess that's why I prefer spending hours on my rock collection, meticulously arranging them by geological age, or just staring at the gears of an old clock and dismantling it over and over; these things don’t change, unlike people or unexpected noises that always distract me. And honestly, sometimes I don’t even notice if I’ve cut myself or if the water is too hot, but other times a scratchy shirt tag can feel like torture, making it hard to adjust to new situations or understand why certain social norms matter.

Honestly, my brain feels like a broken radio, constantly tuning into different stations. I often mess up simple things at work because I get completely sidetracked by a fly buzzing or a distant siren, missing key details and making careless mistakes. It's frustrating because I *want* to pay attention, but my mind just bounces. My body feels the same way; I'm always fidgeting or wanting to get up and walk around, even when I'm supposed to sit still. If my usual route to the store changes, or even if my coffee mug is in the 'wrong' spot, it completely throws me off for the whole day, making me really anxious. Funny thing is, I barely notice if I accidentally burn myself or bump into something hard; it's like a dull ache I can just ignore. But put me in a conversation, and I feel lost; I can't keep up with who's supposed to talk when, and I often zone out or interrupt without meaning to, making it awkward for everyone.

Honestly, my brain is just always buzzing, and I get totally sidetracked by anything – a fly, a noise outside, you name it. Because of that, I often start projects at work or chores at home but just can't seem to finish them, leaving a pile of half-done stuff. It doesn't help that conversations feel like a real effort for me; I struggle to keep them going or even start one, and talking about feelings? Forget it, I just don't know how. This makes it really tough to actually make and keep friends, so I mostly end up on my own. And to top it all off, I have this bad habit of blurting out answers before people even finish their questions, which I know can be annoying. It's like my mouth just goes ahead of my brain sometimes.

I often leave my seat when I'm supposed to be sitting still, like at meetings. When it comes to daily tasks, I make so many careless mistakes because my attention jumps all over the place, and I get distracted by every little thing, so I rarely finish what I start, and forget appointments or where I put my keys daily. My desk is always a mess, and organizing anything feels like an impossible puzzle. But despite all that chaos, I can spend hours, absolutely fixated, on researching old train schedules from the 1950s; I even have this little model train engine I carry around everywhere, and nothing else matters when I'm deep into that. So yeah, my life is a constant whirlwind of movement and forgotten details, punctuated by these intense, focused moments on my specific interests.

Honestly, I feel like I'm constantly running on high-speed, like there's a little motor inside me that just won't quit. Seriously, my keys, my wallet, appointments, what I needed from the store – it all just vanishes from my head the moment I look away. It's like my brain is too busy revving its engine to keep track of the everyday details, leading to a lot of chaos and missed commitments. Sometimes I wish I could just hit the pause button, but that motor just keeps on going.

My daily life often feels like a constant battle between needing things to stay exactly the same and this buzzing energy inside me that just won't quit. Because of this, and honestly, because I don't really get how to "chit-chat" or use hand motions to show what I mean, making friends has always been a real struggle for me; most other people my age just don't seem to get it. If one of them gets moved, even a tiny bit, or if my routine for checking them changes, it throws my whole day off, and I get seriously upset. Honestly, imaginative games or just hanging out and making small talk with other kids always felt pointless to me; I just didn't see the fun in pretending. And in school or at work, if I have to sit still and really focus on something boring for a long time, my brain just checks out, and before I know it, I'm up and pacing around the room. I guess people probably think I'm a bit weird because I don't always look them in the eye or show much expression when I'm talking, but that's just how I am.

And don't even get me started on anything that needs real focus, like filling out forms or reading long reports; my brain just hits a wall, and I'll do anything to avoid those tasks (Avoids or is reluctant to engage in tasks requiring sustained mental effort). Even when I try to sit still, my leg is constantly bouncing under the table, or I'm tapping my fingers (Fidgets with or taps hands or feet or squirms in seat). Sometimes, when I get really overwhelmed or super excited, I catch myself doing this sort of little hand flapping thing, almost like a bird trying to take off (Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements). Social stuff is also a total minefield. I never seem to get the unspoken rules, and I’ve definitely said the wrong thing at the wrong time more than once, making things awkward without meaning to (Difficulties adjusting behavior to suit social contexts or lack of understanding of social norms). It's exhausting trying to navigate a world that doesn't quite fit how my brain works.

Honestly, my life feels like a constant hurricane inside a really strict library. I'm always 'on the go,' like I'm driven by a motor, which makes me fidget with my hands or squirm even when I'm supposed to be still, and I often end up feeling restless, never able to truly relax or engage in quiet activities. This means my desk is always a disaster, I lose things constantly – my keys, my wallet – and I'm super forgetful with daily stuff, missing appointments or making careless mistakes because I can't organize anything or pay close attention to details, especially if a task needs a lot of mental effort, which I tend to avoid anyway. Yet, any small change in my daily schedule or a transition to a new activity completely throws me off, and I have these rigid ways of thinking and rituals, like needing to say things in a specific order. My world revolves around military history – I'm totally fixated on it, collecting old maps and getting super attached to the details of specific uniforms, examining every stitch. When it comes to people, it’s like I’m speaking a different language; I don't get imaginative play, I'm just not interested in making friends or sharing emotions, and I struggle to understand what gestures mean or even make eye contact, which people find weird. During conversations, I talk way too much and often blurt out answers before someone finishes their question, struggling to wait my turn. Plus, loud noises or certain fabric textures are just unbearable to me; it's overwhelming, and all this makes developing and keeping any kind of social relationship incredibly hard.

It's just hard for me to connect with others, you know? I'd much rather spend my time focused on my model airplanes, especially looking at all the tiny rivets on the wings – I can do that for hours without getting bored. Most kids my age just don't get why that's so interesting, and honestly, I don't really care to play their games. I have my own way of doing things, like how I always have to line up my books alphabetically by author's last name, and if someone moves them, it really messes with my head. I find it super confusing trying to figure out what people expect from me in a conversation, so it's tough to even start new friendships, let alone keep them going. It's like there's a secret code everyone else understands that I missed out on. I just prefer my own company and my own little world, where things make sense and stay the same.

My brain feels like it's always running a marathon; I'm constantly 'on the go,' like I'm driven by an internal motor, and I just can't sit still for long, which means I often talk excessively and blurt out answers before anyone's even finished asking. This makes it impossible to wait my turn in conversations, and frankly, I just can't do quiet activities. I'm easily distracted by every little thing, so people often say I don't seem to listen when they're talking to me, and I frequently don't follow through on instructions or finish duties, plus I'm pretty forgetful about daily stuff. Social situations are a real maze because I just don't get the unwritten rules and find it incredibly hard to make or keep friends; I don't really grasp or share emotions, and the natural back-and-forth of conversation just doesn't click for me. People also mention I don't use many facial expressions or gestures, and I've never really understood imaginative play. Any minor change in my routine, like a different lunch time, causes me massive distress, and I stick rigidly to my own verbal patterns, often repeating specific phrases, because they're my anchor. My world revolves around my specific interest in historical lighthouse blueprints, and I can spend hours just looking at the lenses and mechanisms, sometimes even rocking gently when I'm deep in thought or feeling overwhelmed.

My mind and body just don't stop; it feels like I'm always 'on the go,' driven by a motor, which makes it nearly impossible to quietly sit through anything without constantly fidgeting or tapping my feet. This internal buzz also means I often talk excessively, blurting out answers before questions are finished and constantly interrupting others because I just can't wait my turn, totally messing up the flow of conversation. Honestly, even when someone speaks directly to me, it looks like I don't listen, because my brain is so easily distracted by every little thing, and I struggle to understand all those unspoken gestures people use to communicate. Figuring out how to act in different social situations is a huge challenge, and honestly, I don't have much interest in making friends or sharing emotions with peers. Any tiny change in my day, like a different route or a last-minute plan, sends me into complete distress, as I really stick to my non-functional routines. What truly calms me down are my specific interests, like my intense focus on collecting old maps; I get totally fixated on them, spending hours arranging them in a precise order, sometimes even forming unusual attachments to particular ones. But when it comes to chores or work, forget it; I'll start a task, get distracted, and never quite follow through on the instructions, leaving a bunch of duties unfinished because I have difficulty sustaining attention. It's odd too, sometimes I barely notice if I cut myself or bump into something really hard, almost like I'm indifferent to pain.

"Honestly, social stuff has always been a puzzle for me; I've never really gotten the hang of making friends, and other kids my age just didn't seem as interesting as my own thoughts. My mind is constantly buzzing, and I'm always fidgeting, tapping my foot under the table, or squirming in my seat, which probably doesn't help when I'm supposed to be paying attention, so I'll often lose my keys or forget where I put important papers. It’s hard to stay quiet, so I often blurt out things or interrupt people mid-sentence, especially when I get distracted by some random sound or thought, and I swear, I just can't keep my hands still or sit still in general. People always tell me my face doesn't show much, and I struggle to understand what their gestures mean, or how I should act in different situations, like a fancy dinner versus a casual barbecue. I prefer to spend hours just lining up my old coin collection or watching the washing machine spin, sometimes flapping my hands when I get really into it, and I often catch myself repeating certain phrases over and over. Any sudden change in my routine completely throws me off, making me super agitated, and because my brain is always running a million miles an hour, I tend to rush things and make silly, careless mistakes. It’s like I have this internal motor that just won't stop, making it impossible to be quiet or still, and I find myself running around or climbing things when I really shouldn't be."

My life feels like a constant tug-of-war; I'm always 'on the go' and fidgeting my hands or feet, like there's a motor inside me that never quits. I often forget important appointments or chores, and I'll blurt out an answer before someone even finishes their question, interrupting everyone because waiting my turn feels impossible. Socially, it's a minefield; I really struggle to understand how to connect with people, often missing gestures or the natural back-and-forth of a conversation, and sometimes I find myself repeating the same phrases over and over. My world revolves around my collection of vintage maps, which I have an intense, almost obsessive focus on, and any tiny change to my daily routine or a shift in plans sends me into a complete meltdown; I need things to be exactly right. Certain noises, like a loud fan, are torture to my ears, but I barely notice if I accidentally burn myself on the stove. And frankly, the whole idea of make-believe or playing games with open-ended rules just doesn't make sense to me.

My mind feels like a thousand tabs open at once, jumping from one thing to another; it's why I can barely keep my attention on tasks and constantly make careless mistakes or fail to finish what I start. This internal chaos clashes hard with my deep need for things to be *just so*; even a small change to my daily plans or a different route home can send me spiraling, and I struggle terribly with any transitions. Socially, I often feel like I'm reading a foreign language; I just don't get most gestures people use, and I have a bad habit of blurting out answers or interrupting folks mid-sentence because waiting my turn feels impossible. It makes developing and keeping any kind of friendship or relationship really tough, honestly. What I *can* concentrate on are my specific fixations, like spending hours meticulously categorizing different types of historical coins; they are my whole world, and I've got this super strong attachment to my rare Roman denarius. But even in that focus, my body won't cooperate; I constantly feel restless, like I need to run about, and I just can't engage in quiet activities, always fidgeting or moving. And then there's the sensory stuff: the hum of the fridge feels like a roar sometimes, and certain clothing textures are just unbearable, though weirdly, I sometimes don't even notice if I've hurt myself.

Honestly, my daily life feels like a constant battle against myself. I know it can be frustrating for others, but it's just how my mind works, trying to keep up with itself and the rigid patterns I rely on.

My mind is like a wild rollercoaster that's also stuck on a single track. It doesn't help that I don't really get how people expect me to act in different social situations, or why certain hand gestures mean what they do; I often miss those unspoken social cues entirely. Because of all this, making and keeping friends is a huge struggle; I don't really know how to do the natural back-and-forth chat, and honestly, I'm not that interested in what my peers are up to anyway, nor do I share my own feelings much. My focus is a mess; I struggle to pay attention to tasks, making careless mistakes constantly, and if something requires me to really concentrate for a while, I'll avoid it completely or just forget it altogether, like appointments or where I put my keys. Instead, my brain latches onto specific things, like endlessly studying old train schedules or just staring at the spinning wheels on my toy cars – I find a strange comfort in those repetitive movements, sometimes even flapping my hands when I'm really excited. Any small change to my routine, like my morning coffee mug being in the wrong spot, can really throw me off and make me feel incredibly anxious. It’s weird, too, because sometimes I won't even notice if I've cut myself or touched something super hot; it's like my body just doesn't register the pain or temperature properly.

People often say I don't seem to listen when they talk directly to me, but my mind is just racing, and I can't help but fidget with my hands or tap my foot constantly. Because of this, and honestly, I struggle with the whole back-and-forth of conversations, so I often just interrupt others or blurt out my thoughts without meaning to be rude. If you get me talking about medieval siege warfare, though, it's a different story; I can go on for hours, using all sorts of rigid phrases, because that's my highly restricted, fixated interest. Making friends is a real challenge for me; I just don't get why kids my age do what they do, and I never know what gestures to use or how to read theirs. Oh, and don't even get me started on changes – even a small shift in my schedule or activity can throw my whole day off, and I’m always forgetting important stuff, like appointments, in the chaos.

My whole life feels like a constant battle, like my brain is running too fast and too slow all at once, and it makes everything a mess. I'm always forgetting things, misplacing my keys, and my desk is a disaster zone; I just can't seem to organize my tasks or pay close attention, making careless mistakes constantly. I get so easily distracted by any little thing, so when someone talks directly to me, it's like their words just don't stick, and I avoid tasks that need a lot of sustained mental effort. Then there's the motor inside me that never stops; I'm always fidgeting, tapping my feet, or just feeling restless, like I need to run around even when it's not appropriate, and I can't play quietly for anything. This also means I talk way too much, blurting out answers before anyone finishes their question, and I interrupt people constantly because waiting my turn is just impossible. Social stuff is a whole other level of confusing; I never know what to do with my face or hands when I talk, and I struggle to understand what gestures people are trying to use, making it hard to follow conversations or build real relationships since I don't quite get sharing emotions or imaginative play. What I really care about are my fixated interests, like ancient civilizations; I can spend hours deep into them, but I get extremely distressed if anything in my strict routine changes, even small stuff, and I have these really rigid ways of thinking. I also find myself flapping my hands or rocking when I'm overwhelmed, and certain sounds or textures drive me absolutely nuts, but then sometimes I don't even notice if I've hurt myself, and people often say I use strange, repetitive phrases.

My life feels like a constant battle between a buzzing internal motor and a strict rulebook I've made for myself. Because of this constant buzz, I'm always making silly, careless mistakes at work, missing important details in reports, and I'm so forgetful that I'm constantly losing my keys or forgetting appointments. My desk is a complete mess; I can never seem to get my tasks or stuff organized. Even when I'm supposed to be still, like in a meeting, I feel this intense need to get up and move around, sometimes even pacing, and I definitely struggle to wait my turn in conversations, often just blurting things out. People often tell me I don't show much expression or make eye contact when they talk to me, and I know I sometimes use really formal or unusual words that nobody else seems to use, even repeating phrases I've heard. I've cut myself before and not even noticed until much later, like I'm just numb to some things, but I can spend hours just lining up my old action figures or spinning the wheels on toy cars, completely lost in it. Any little change in my routine, even something tiny like a different route to the store, can throw my whole day off and make me feel incredibly distressed. It's a confusing way to live, always moving but also needing everything to stay exactly the same, and trying to communicate when the unspoken rules just don't make sense to me.

Honestly, my body just won't quit; I feel like I'm constantly 'on the go,' like I have a motor running inside me. It's impossible for me to just sit still, even when I'm supposed to be playing quietly or sitting in a meeting; I often get up from my seat, my legs are always tapping or I'm squirming, and I just feel restless all the time. This makes it really hard to get organized, and I'm always forgetting important stuff, like appointments or where my keys are. People often get annoyed because I talk way too much, sometimes repeating the same phrases, and I don't always make eye contact or show much expression when we chat. It's like I don't even hear them when they're talking directly to me. Instead, my brain is usually fixated on my specific interests, like just staring at the spinning wheels of my toy cars or collecting old train tickets, which I'm super into. I'll rush through tasks, making silly, careless mistakes because I missed a detail. And weirdly, I barely notice if I bump into something or get a little cut; it's like I don't feel pain as much as other people. Plus, I don't really care to start conversations or even connect with friends.

Man, my life is a constant hunt for stuff. Keys, wallet, that specific screwdriver I *always* need for my model trains – they just vanish into thin air, and it drives me nuts because I rely on them for my projects. Speaking of my trains, they're not just toys; each locomotive has its own story, its own personality, and I spend hours arranging them just so on their tracks. I get really upset if anyone touches them, it's like they're family. Because of this, and honestly, because I just don't get why people pretend a stick is a sword or a doll is a baby, I never really got into all that imaginative play as a kid. I much preferred sticking to the rules of my train sets, where everything made sense. It's tough sometimes, feeling so attached to things and then losing them, while other people seem to just *get* how to play and connect without all this fuss.

My mind feels like it's running five different programs at once, all while trying to download a huge file, so it's no wonder I can't stay focused on one thing for long or get easily sidetracked by every little noise around me. Because of that, I rarely finish what I start, whether it's chores or work projects, and just can't seem to follow instructions all the way through. But if it's about ancient civilizations or coding, I can talk for hours, deep-diving into every detail, much to the dismay of anyone trying to have a "normal" conversation; that's my real passion, though it feels like an unusual thing to care about so much. Socially, I just don't get it; I don't really bother trying to make friends, and I struggle to understand why people move their hands or make certain faces to express things – it all just goes over my head, and my own face probably doesn't show much either. And forget about waiting my turn or letting someone finish their thought; I'm usually blurting out my own idea or interrupting before they're done. Even when I'm supposed to be relaxing, I'm always tapping my foot or fidgeting in my seat, just unable to engage in anything quietly, like there's a constant buzz under my skin. Any unexpected change to my routine, like a different route to work or a sudden plan change, completely throws me off, and I'll even repeat certain phrases or use very specific wording because it just feels "right." Plus, certain sounds or textures can really set me off, feeling like an actual physical assault, which makes navigating the world pretty intense.

My brain feels like a thousand tabs open at once, constantly battling the world's expectations. I'll be in a conversation and completely miss what someone said directly to me because a dust mote caught my eye, and I'm always misplacing my stuff, like keys or my phone. It's tough for me to wait my turn; I just blurt out whatever comes to mind and often end up repeating myself. My face doesn't really show what I'm thinking, and I don't use many hand gestures, which probably confuses people. I've got this internal motor going all the time; I can't stay seated, so I'm always fidgeting or tapping my hands and feet. Sometimes I just feel the need to run or climb, which isn't great in a library, and I really struggle to just sit and do something quiet. My comfort zone is deeply rooted in my obsession with old train schedules and railway history; I can spend hours just sorting information, sometimes rocking back and forth when I'm really focused or stressed. Any small change in my daily routine or having to switch tasks can make me completely shut down because I stick to my own way of doing things. Oh, and sometimes I barely notice if I accidentally burn myself, it's like I don't even feel it. Growing up, I never really got the hang of make-believe games; I much preferred actual facts. It's just a different way my brain works, I guess.

My life feels like a constant scramble; I'm always losing my keys or phone, and my desk is usually a disaster, making it impossible to organize anything properly. Even when I try to sit still, my feet are tapping, or I'm fidgeting with something, because I feel like I'm always 'on the go,' like I have a motor inside me, so I often get up and wander around, even during meetings when I should really be seated. Plus, if my usual routine changes even a little, like a different route to the store, it can really throw me off and make me super distressed.

Honestly, sometimes I feel like my brain just won't cooperate with the rest of the world. Take, for instance, a work meeting; I know I should stay put, but I just can't sit still for long. I'll often find myself getting up to pace around the room, needing to move even when it's totally unexpected. This is especially true if someone brings up my main thing: antique pocket watches. I'm completely obsessed with them, and my prize piece, a tarnished old railroad watch, feels like my most precious companion, almost alive to me. I can spend hours just staring at its tiny gears, completely mesmerized by the intricate movement. And if an idea about it pops into my head, I'll totally interrupt whoever is talking, just blurting out facts about its escapement mechanism before they've even finished their sentence. My family says I'm rude, but it's like my thoughts just escape before I can catch them. It's tough trying to keep all these different parts of me in check.

My mind is always buzzing, which means I often rush through things and make really careless mistakes, like totally messing up instructions on a task. The worst part is when plans change; if we suddenly have to do something different or switch activities, it completely throws me off and makes me really upset. It's like my brain just can't handle going from one thing to another without a huge fuss.

My head often feels like a broken radio, jumping channels and making it so hard to pay attention to anything for more than a minute, especially if it's boring, which means I make a ton of careless mistakes and never seem to finish anything I start. My brain feels like it's running a marathon all the time; I can't just sit and chill out, even when I'm supposed to be relaxing or having fun. My brain feels like it's running a hundred miles an hour while simultaneously being stuck in quicksand. My brain feels like it’s constantly running a million miles an hour; I’m always 'on the go' and even when I try to be still, my foot taps like crazy or my fingers drum on the table. My mind feels like a constantly swirling storm; I'm always misplacing things and forgetting daily appointments, which makes organizing even simple tasks a huge struggle. My kid, Leo, bless his heart, is a whirlwind; his room looks like a disaster zone most days, and trying to get him to organize his school stuff is a constant battle. He rarely shares his feelings unless you press him, and when you're talking to him, he often doesn't make eye contact, and it's like he doesn't pick up on hints or body language, just not grasping the back-and-forth of a conversation. My main joy comes from spending hours intensely focused on collecting vintage maps, exploring their intricate details with magnifying glasses, almost obsessively using these objects to study them.

My body just has a mind of its own, honestly. I find it almost impossible to stay put, especially during those endless meetings at work, so I'm always getting up and pacing a bit around the room. Honestly, my kid is like a human dynamo, always 'on the go' from the moment he wakes up, and he just never stops talking, blurting out whatever pops into his head. It's tough in conversations because he'll often just interrupt you mid-sentence, and half the time, it feels like he's not even listening when you're talking directly to him. We can't sit through dinner without him constantly leaving his seat, sometimes even running around the house, which is a nightmare when coupled with his hypersensitivity to sounds; even a loud television can send him spiraling. His mind is totally fixated on trains; he knows every model, every route, and if you try to get him to play make-believe with a toy car, he just looks confused, like, "What's the point?" He also has these specific phrases he'll repeat over and over, and everything has to be done *just so*, like his morning routine; if we change one tiny thing, it's a huge meltdown. It's not just the words; he struggles to get the back-and-forth of talking, almost like he's missing a beat in the rhythm of conversation, making it really hard to connect sometimes. It's like his brain has two different speeds: super-fast and super-stuck, making everyday life a constant challenge for all of us.

Honestly, my mind is a whirlwind. I can barely focus on anything for more than a few minutes, which means I make a ton of careless mistakes at work and half the time, I don't even hear what people are saying directly to me. I'm constantly losing my keys or wallet and forgetting appointments – it's a disaster. My body feels like it's got a motor running all the time; I just can't sit still, so I'm always tapping my foot or getting up, even when I'm supposed to be quiet. Socially, it's rough. I never know how to act in different situations and I miss all the subtle hand movements or facial expressions people use. I'm not really into chatting about feelings or imaginary games, preferring to spend hours with my collection of antique doorknobs – I love examining every little detail. People say I'm rude because I blurt things out or can't wait my turn, but I just don't get why it's a big deal. Also, I barely notice if I get a cut or burn myself; pain just doesn't register the same way for me. I guess making friends is just not something that comes easy.

My brain feels like a tornado in a library; everything's flying around and trying to stick to its own strict order at the same time. I'm always forgetting appointments and losing things, and it’s a struggle to finish anything I start, even simple instructions feel like they're written in a foreign language. I’ll get super focused on my special interests, like historical maps, for hours without noticing anything else, but for other tasks, I'm easily distracted by every little noise or shadow, leading to loads of careless mistakes. My body always feels like it’s got a motor running; I’m constantly tapping my foot or squirming, and I often blurt out answers or talk way too much, even cutting people off before they finish their sentences because waiting my turn is just so hard. Socially, it’s a minefield; I struggle with the back-and-forth of conversation, people say I don't make eye contact, and I definitely miss all those unspoken cues and gestures that everyone else seems to get, often not seeming to listen when spoken to directly. I honestly don’t get why someone would want to talk about feelings, and I find it really tough to start or keep up conversations about anything that isn't my current obsession, so making friends just isn't something I naturally pursue. Any change in my routine, even a tiny one like a different breakfast cereal, can send me into a real panic, and loud noises or certain fabric textures feel like physical pain. When I get overwhelmed, I find myself flapping my hands or rocking back and forth, and I just can't seem to figure out how to act 'right' in different social situations, often using the same formal phrases over and over.

Honestly, my mind is always buzzing, and it feels like I'm constantly 'on the go,' like I've got a motor running inside me that just won't quit, so I'm often unable to play or engage in leisure activities quietly. My whole world revolves around my collection of antique toy cars; I've got this one rare model, and I have such an unusual attachment to it that I even sleep with it. If anyone so much as bumps my display shelf, or if anything in my daily routine changes even a tiny bit, I get excessively distressed. People often get annoyed because I just blurt out answers before they're done asking the question, and honestly, I don't really get why that's a problem or how I'm supposed to adjust my behavior to suit different social contexts. I never really understood imaginative or spontaneous social play as a kid; it just felt so pointless. Oh, and those bright fluorescent lights in stores? They make my skin crawl (hypersensitivity), yet sometimes I won't even notice if I've cut myself while working on my models (hyporeactivity). All this means I sometimes fail to give close attention to details and make careless mistakes because my focus jumps so much, unless it's on my cars, of course.

My life feels like a constant battle against my own brain; it's genuinely exhausting. I'm always losing my keys, phone, or other important stuff, and my workspace is a complete disaster because organizing tasks and activities just feels impossible. I'm constantly 'on the go,' like there's a motor running inside me; even when sitting, I'm fidgeting with my hands or tapping my feet, and waiting my turn, whether in line or conversation, is pure torture. This constant movement makes it incredibly hard to sustain attention on anything for long, and I'm often forgetful about daily things like appointments. Socially, it's a mess: I struggle to make friends or connect with people my age, mostly because I don't get the whole back-and-forth of conversation or how to adjust my behavior for different social settings. I also couldn't get into imaginative play as a kid. And the sensory stuff is brutal: loud noises or certain fabric textures drive me crazy, while sometimes I don't even notice if I've cut myself; plus, any tiny change to my routine sends me into a tailspin. Sometimes, when I'm really stressed, I'll even flap my hands a bit.

My whole day feels like it's built on a delicate house of cards, and any tiny change in my schedule, even something small like a meeting moving, totally throws me off and makes me feel completely derailed. Once I'm off track, my brain just can't seem to focus on anything, and every little sound or movement around me becomes this huge distraction. I'll be trying to work on something, and suddenly I'm looking out the window or thinking about what I'm having for dinner, which usually means I miss important stuff or make really dumb, careless mistakes. Even when I try to relax or do something fun, it's impossible for me to just sit still and be quiet. My family always tells me to calm down, but I just can't; it's like I have this internal motor always running, making me fidget or need to move around constantly. So, forget about reading a book or watching a movie without squirming or having to get up multiple times. This constant need to move, combined with getting sidetracked by everything, makes getting through my day without a hitch almost impossible, especially if there's any unexpected curveball.

Honestly, my brain feels like a broken record player that keeps skipping through thoughts. I'm always forgetting things, like where I put my keys five minutes ago or that appointment I had yesterday morning. And when I do get on a topic, I tend to talk your ear off about it, sometimes without even realizing I'm dominating the whole conversation. It's not just my mouth; my body is always on the go too. I feel like I'm constantly buzzing with energy, like there's a motor inside me that just won't quit, making me feel restless. Because of that, trying to just sit down and chill with a book or a movie quietly? Forget about it – I just can't sit still for long. People often tell me I have a serious face, or that it's hard to tell what I'm thinking because I don't use many hand gestures or change my expression much when I speak. It's not intentional, it's just how I am.

My life often feels like I'm constantly trying to catch a train that's already left the station, while also trying to wear a scratchy sweater in a too-bright room. I'm always bouncing around, can't sit still for long – I'll be up and down from my chair twenty times a day, and forget about getting anything organized; my desk is a disaster, and I constantly lose my keys or forget appointments. I absolutely hate tasks that need me to really hunker down and concentrate; my brain just says 'nope' to sustained mental effort. If you try to talk to me when I'm in the middle of something, I probably won't even hear you because my mind just wanders off, easily pulled by any tiny sound or movement. When I do talk, people say my face doesn't show much, and I don't make eye contact easily, sometimes repeating certain phrases or using strange words that only make sense to me. I find comfort in my collection of old antique doorknobs – I could spend hours just spinning them or arranging them by their specific type of brass, but other things, like the hum of the fridge or certain rough fabrics, just drive me absolutely nuts. Honestly, I never really understood pretend play as a kid, or even now with my niece; it just doesn't click for me, and I prefer to be alone with my collections anyway.

My brain feels like two different people are fighting in there all the time: one is a whirlwind, and the other needs everything perfectly still. I'm always losing my keys and forgetting appointments, and my desk is a disaster zone because I just can't seem to get anything organized, so trying to tackle boring paperwork feels like pulling teeth and I put it off until the last minute. Any little sound or movement will pull my attention away, and honestly, I always feel this restless energy buzzing inside me, like I constantly need to get up and move; sitting still for a movie or a quiet game is nearly impossible for me. But then there's the other part of me that absolutely needs things to stay the same; if my morning routine changes even a little, or if someone moves my collection of vintage maps, I get incredibly upset and might even have a meltdown. I also find myself saying the same specific phrases over and over, almost like a verbal ritual. Socially, it's a minefield; I struggle to understand how to act in different situations and often just don't get why people find certain things offensive. People sometimes tell me my face looks blank, and I don't really use many hand gestures when I talk, which makes it tough to connect with others or keep friends for very long. It’s like I'm trying to navigate a world that demands flexibility and social finesse, but my internal GPS is stuck on 'rigid routine' and 'distraction highway' simultaneously.

My kid, bless his heart, just isn't wired like other kids when it comes to people. He never really gets into the back-and-forth chit-chat, and honestly, he doesn't seem all that bothered by not having a big group of friends his age. Trying to get him to open up about his feelings or understand someone else's? Forget about it. And sitting still for a minute is like asking him to hold his breath forever. If we're playing a game, he can barely wait his turn; he just blurts out answers or tries to go next right away, usually making noise while he does it. Forget about him quietly playing with his toys or chilling out with a book; it's always got to be loud or active, or he's bouncing off the walls. The biggest headache, though, is any change to our routine. If the schedule shifts or we have to switch activities unexpectedly, it's a guaranteed meltdown. It's like his whole world gets turned upside down just because dinner is five minutes late, making every day a bit of a challenge.

My brain feels like a broken radio, always jumping channels, making it really tough to stick with one task because I get distracted by every little thing around me.
